Over the past two decades, unfavorable views towards both major U.S. political parties among independents have shown notable fluctuations. At their peak in 2015, more than a third of independents (36%) held unfavorable views of both parties, but this figure has declined in recent years [9]. However, a significant portion of independents who do not lean toward either party still hold negative views of both, with 37% expressing unfavorable opinions [2]. Additionally, 22% of these non-leaning independents have favorable opinions of both parties, while only 11% view the Democratic Party favorably and 9% view the GOP favorably [2].

![Unfavorable views of both parties have fluctuated, peaking in 2015 with 36% and declining since.](image1)

Among independents who lean toward a party, views are more polarized. Republican-leaning independents are almost as likely as Republican identifiers to view the Democratic Party negatively (81% unfavorable), while Democratic-leaning independents mirror this with 84% unfavorable views of the GOP [3]. This intense dislike has surged over the past two decades, with very unfavorable opinions of the opposing party more than quadrupling since 1994 [6].

![The surge in very unfavorable views of the opposing party since 1994 is evident among both Republican and Democratic leaners.](image6)

Demographic differences also play a role in these views. For example, non-leaning independents are more likely to have unfavorable opinions of both parties compared to those who lean toward a party [8]. Additionally, while independents who lean toward a party often mirror the views of their affiliated counterparts, their levels of agreement vary depending on the issue [4]. For instance, Republican-leaning independents are less supportive of Donald Trump than Republican identifiers, but 70% still approved of his job performance during his first two years in office [5].

![Demographic breakdown of independents, including differences in gender, race, age, and education, influences their views of the parties.](image2)

In summary, unfavorable views of both parties among independents peaked in 2015 and have since declined, but non-leaning independents remain more likely to hold negative views of both. Leaners, however, exhibit strong partisan imprints, with high levels of negativity toward the opposing party and alignment with their affiliated party's views.

Over the past two decades, unfavorable views toward the opposing party have surged across all political affiliations. Among Democratic-leaning independents, the share with a very unfavorable opinion of the Republican Party increased from 8% in 1994 to 37% in 2018 [2]. Similarly, Republican-leaning independents with very unfavorable views of the Democratic Party rose from 15% in 1994 to 39% in 2018 [2]. Among partisan identifiers, 87% of Republicans and 88% of Democrats currently view the opposing party unfavorably, with Republican-leaning independents closely following at 81% unfavorability toward the Democratic Party [3].

![Unfavorable views toward opposing parties have risen significantly since 1994.](image4)

Independents who do not lean toward either party are more likely to hold unfavorable views of both parties, with 37% expressing this sentiment [6], up from 36% in 2015 [9]. However, the share of independents who view both parties negatively has declined slightly in recent years [9]. Currently, 22% of non-leaning independents have favorable opinions of both parties, while only 11% view the Democratic Party favorably and 9% the Republican Party favorably [6].

![Independents without party leanings are more likely to hold unfavorable views of both parties.](image5)

In summary, unfavorable views of the opposing party have risen sharply among partisans and leaning independents, while non-leaning independents remain the most likely group to view both parties negatively, though this percentage has seen a slight decline in recent years.

Republicans and Democrats hold notably different views on China’s handling of the coronavirus outbreak and its impact on U.S.-China relations. Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are far more critical of China’s response to the pandemic. For instance, **$82\%$** of Republicans say China has done a bad job dealing with the coronavirus, compared to **$54\%$** of Democrats [10]. Additionally, Republicans are nearly twice as likely to believe China has done a *very* bad job (**$\tilde{6}1\%$** vs. **$30\%$**) [10].

Republicans are also significantly more likely to blame China for the global spread of the virus. **$73\%$** of Republicans believe China’s early handling of the pandemic contributed a great deal to its spread, compared to **$38\%$** of Democrats [5]. This partisan divide extends to policy preferences, with **$71\%$** of Republicans supporting holding China responsible for its role in the outbreak, even if it worsens economic relations, while only **$37\%$** of Democrats share this view [9].

![Republicans are more critical of China's pandemic response than Democrats](image3)

Democrats, on the other hand, are more inclined to prioritize strong U.S.-China relations, with **$38\%$** favoring this approach even if it means overlooking China’s role in the outbreak [9]. This stark contrast highlights the deeper skepticism and tougher stances Republicans hold toward China compared to Democrats.

Republicans and Democrats differ significantly in their perceptions of China’s handling of COVID-19, with Republicans being more critical. For instance, **82% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents** say China has done a bad job dealing with the coronavirus, compared to **54% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents**. Republicans are also about twice as likely to think China has done a **very bad job** (61% vs. 30%) [3][10].

Moreover, **73% of Republicans** believe China’s early handling of the pandemic contributed a **great deal** to its global spread, while only **38% of Democrats** share this view [7]. This partisan divide is further evident in attitudes toward holding China accountable: **71% of Republicans** support holding China responsible even if it worsens economic relations, compared to **37% of Democrats** [3]. ![Republicans are more likely to blame China for the global spread of COVID-19](image1)

Over time, negative perceptions of China have increased across the political spectrum. In 2019, **63% of Republicans** and **61% of Democrats** viewed economic ties with China as bad. By 2020, these numbers rose to **73% of Democrats** and **63% of Republicans**, reflecting a growing skepticism toward China [4]. ![Negative views of U.S.-China economic ties have increased among both Republicans and Democrats](image3)

In summary, Republicans are far more critical of China’s COVID-19 response and its role in the pandemic’s spread, and these negative perceptions have intensified over time for both parties.

Americans’ views on China’s role in the coronavirus outbreak and U.S.-China relations vary significantly, with notable differences across political affiliations. Around three-quarters of Americans believe the Chinese government’s initial handling of the coronavirus outbreak in Wuhan contributed either a great deal (51%) or a fair amount (27%) to the global spread of the virus [4]. Republicans are particularly critical, with 73% attributing a great deal of blame to China, compared to 38% of Democrats [4]. Older individuals are also more likely to fault China’s early response [4].

Negative perceptions of China’s handling of the outbreak correlate with unfavorable views of the country. For instance, 85% of those who say China did a poor job handling the pandemic have an unfavorable view of China, compared to 53% among those who think it did a good job [3]. Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more likely to say China has done a bad job dealing with the virus (82%) than Democrats and Democratic leaners (54%) [8].

When it comes to U.S.-China relations, half of Americans think the U.S. should hold China responsible for its role in the pandemic, even if it means worsening economic relations, while 38% prioritize strong U.S.-China relations [7]. Republicans are twice as likely (71%) as Democrats (37%) to support holding China accountable at the expense of economic ties [7].

![Visualization of U.S. priorities regarding China’s role in the outbreak](image1)

![Breakdown of views on China’s role in the outbreak by political affiliation](image3)

In summary, Americans are largely critical of China’s role in the coronavirus outbreak, with Republicans and older individuals being more likely to blame China. Political affiliation significantly influences opinions on whether the U.S. should prioritize holding China accountable or maintaining strong bilateral relations.

American perceptions of China’s role in handling COVID-19 and broader U.S.-China relations have significantly soured in recent years, with a notable decline in favorability and increased blame placed on China for the pandemic’s global spread.  

![The Chinese government's initial handling of the coronavirus outbreak in Wuhan is largely blamed for the global spread](image1)  
Around **78% of Americans** attribute a great deal or fair amount of blame to the Chinese government for its initial handling of the COVID-19 outbreak in Wuhan. This sentiment is reinforced by the fact that **64% of Americans** believe China has done a bad job dealing with the coronavirus outbreak [7]. Those who fault China’s role in the pandemic are significantly more likely to hold unfavorable views of the country, with **85%** of this group expressing negative opinions [9].  

Negative perceptions of China have sharply increased, with **73% of U.S. adults** now holding an unfavorable view of the country, up **26 percentage points since 2018** and **7 points since March** alone [5]. This decline is closely tied to the widespread belief that China mishandled the outbreak and its subsequent spread [5].  

Economic ties between the U.S. and China are also viewed pessimistically. **68% of Americans** describe current economic relations as being in bad shape, a **15-point increase since May 2019**, during the height of trade tensions [8]. While **51% of Americans** favor pursuing a strong economic relationship with China, **46% advocate for getting tough on China economically**, reflecting a divided but increasingly critical stance [2].  

Moreover, **50% of Americans** believe the U.S. should hold China responsible for its role in the outbreak, even if it worsens economic relations, compared to **38%** who prioritize maintaining strong ties [2]. This sentiment is particularly strong among Republicans, with **71%** supporting holding China accountable, compared to **37% of Democrats** [10].  

![Americans' unfavorable views of China have steadily increased over the years](image4)  
Over time, unfavorable views of China have risen sharply, from **37% in 2005** to **73% in 2020**, indicating a dramatic shift in public opinion [4].  

In summary, American perceptions of China’s handling of COVID-19 and broader U.S.-China relations have worsened significantly, with increased blame placed on China for the pandemic, declining economic optimism, and a growing preference for holding China accountable.

Negative perceptions of China have significantly intensified over time, with notable differences across age groups and political affiliations. 
![Perception of China by age group](image3) shows that among Americans aged 50 and older, unfavorable views of China have risen sharply, reaching 81% as of the latest survey, a 10-point increase since March. Younger age groups, while less negative, also show growing unfavorable views: 71% of those aged 30–49 and 56% of those under 30 hold negative perceptions. ![Perception of China by political affiliation](image5) highlights the partisan divide: Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are significantly more likely (83%) to have unfavorable views of China compared to Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents (68%). This gap has widened, with Republicans now 15 points more negative than Democrats, up from a smaller difference in earlier years. ![Comparison of views on China by age and party affiliation](image1) further illustrates these trends, emphasizing the consistency of negative views across education levels and genders.

Overall, negative perceptions of China have reached historic highs, with older Americans and Republicans exhibiting the most unfavorable views.

Unfavorable views of China in the United States have significantly increased over time, particularly in recent years, with notable differences across age groups and political affiliations. ![Unfavorable views have risen sharply across age groups](image2)

Unfavorable views are most pronounced among older Americans. **81% of those aged 50 and older** have a negative view of China, compared to **71% of those aged 30-49** and **56% of those under 30**. Views among the 50+ age group have increased by **10 percentage points since March**[9].

![Older Americans hold significantly more unfavorable views than younger age groups](image4)

In summary, unfavorable views of China have risen sharply across all demographics, with Republicans and older Americans holding the most negative opinions. This trend has intensified in recent years, particularly due to events like the coronavirus pandemic and growing geopolitical tensions.

Views on China vary significantly across age groups and political affiliations, and these perceptions have shifted notably over time.

In the U.S., political affiliation significantly influences preferences for foreign policy partners and desired cooperation levels. Both Democrats and Republicans agree that the UK is their most important partner, but Republicans are more inclined toward Israel (26%) compared to Democrats (9%) [8]. Democrats also prioritize Canada and Mexico more than Republicans [8]. While views on Germany are similar across parties, ranking it fifth on their lists, Republicans are more likely to prefer close relations with Russia (31%) than Democrats (21%) [4]. Additionally, Republicans are more supportive of increased cooperation with Russia (41%) compared to Democrats (32%) [5]. 

In Germany, partisan differences are less pronounced but still present. Supporters of the CDU/CSU are more willing to cooperate with the U.S. than those aligned with the Greens or SPD [3]. Across political affiliations, Germans consistently name France as their top partner, followed by the U.S. [9]. However, East Germans show a stronger preference for closer ties with Russia (75%) compared to West Germans (63%), reflecting regional political divides [5][7].

![U.S. party preferences for foreign policy partners](image2)  
![German political affiliations and cooperation preferences](image5)  

Overall, in the U.S., Republicans lean toward Israel and Russia, while Democrats emphasize Canada and Mexico, whereas in Germany, political affiliations influence cooperation preferences with the U.S., with regional differences further shaping attitudes toward Russia.

When examining preferences for increased cooperation with Russia and China, Americans and Germans show notable differences, influenced by geography and political affiliations. Germans are almost twice as likely as Americans to want greater collaboration with Russia, with 75% of East Germans and 63% of West Germans favoring it, compared to 41% of Republicans and 32% of Democrats in the U.S. [3]. 

![Germans are more likely than Americans to prefer increased cooperation with Russia.](image1)

In the U.S., Republicans are slightly more inclined than Democrats to support closer ties with Russia (31% vs. 21%) [2]. Meanwhile, German supporters of the CDU/CSU are more willing to cooperate with the U.S. than those backing the Greens and SPD, reflecting ideological divides in international perspectives [9].

![Republicans in the U.S. are more likely than Democrats to prefer closer ties with Russia.](image3)

Regarding China, Germans are about twice as likely to prefer a close relationship with the U.S. over China (50% to 24%), while Americans are nearly evenly split, with 41% favoring Germany and 44% preferring China [10]. Younger Americans (ages 18-29) are more likely to prioritize ties with China (58%) over Germany (32%), a trend that reverses among older Americans [4].

![Younger Americans prioritize ties with China, while older Americans favor Germany.](image5)

In summary, Germans show stronger preferences for cooperation with Russia and the U.S. over China, while Americans are more divided, with partisan and generational factors significantly shaping these views.

In the U.S., political affiliation significantly shapes attitudes toward cooperation with Russia and China. Republicans are more likely than Democrats to prefer closer ties with Russia (31% vs. 21%) and China (44% vs. 41%) [5][6]. Democrats, on the other hand, show a stronger preference for cooperation with Germany (66%) compared to Republicans (57%) [5]. ![Republicans lean more toward Russia, while Democrats favor Germany and China](image1)

In Germany, ideological divides within political parties also influence these preferences. Supporters of the CDU/CSU, a center-right party, are more willing to cooperate with the U.S. than supporters of the Greens and SPD, who lean left [1]. However, when it comes to Russia, Germans overall are more open to collaboration than Americans, with stronger support in the former East Germany (75%) compared to the former West (63%) [3]. ![CDU/CSU favors the U.S., while the Greens and SPD show more openness to other partners](image1)

Regarding China, Germans are twice as likely to prefer closer ties with the U.S. over China (50% vs. 24%), while Americans are more divided, with 41% favoring Germany and 44% preferring China [6]. Younger Americans (18-29) are particularly more likely to prioritize China over Germany (58% vs. 32%) [10]. ![Younger Americans lean toward China, while older Americans favor Germany](image2)

Overall, political party preferences in both countries create distinct patterns in attitudes toward cooperation, with conservatives in both nations leaning toward Russia and the U.S., while liberals tend to favor multilateral organizations like the UN and EU [7].

In the U.S., political affiliations significantly influence attitudes toward cooperation with Russia. Republicans are more inclined to favor increased collaboration with Russia (41%) compared to Democrats (32%)[2]. This partisan divide is also evident when choosing between close relationships with Russia or Germany. About 31% of Republicans prefer closer ties with Russia, while only 21% of Democrats share this preference[4]. ![Republicans in the U.S. are more likely to support cooperation with Russia compared to Democrats](image3).

In Germany, the political landscape shows a different dynamic. Supporters of the CDU/CSU, a center-right party, are more willing to seek greater cooperation with the U.S. than those who support the Greens or the SPD (center-left parties)[3]. However, when it comes to Russia, Germans living in former East Germany are far more supportive of a close relationship with Russia (75%) compared to those in former West Germany (63%)[2][7]. ![Germans in former East Germany prioritize relations with Russia over the U.S.](image7).

Moreover, ideological differences within both countries further highlight these trends. Conservative Americans and Germans on the right of the ideological spectrum are more likely to view Russia favorably than their liberal counterparts[9]. ![Conservative Americans and Germans are more favorable toward Russia than liberals](image5). In contrast, liberals and those on the left are more likely to favor the UN and EU, reflecting a broader ideological divide in attitudes toward international cooperation[9].

In summary, political affiliations in the U.S. and Germany play a crucial role in shaping attitudes toward cooperation with Russia, with Republicans and East Germans showing greater support than Democrats and West Germans.

Americans and Germans hold notably different views on the world’s leading economic power and their international relationships with entities like the EU and China. Half of Americans name the U.S. as the top economic power, while only 24% of Germans agree. In contrast, 53% of Germans see China as the leading economic power, compared to 32% of Americans [2]. ![Americans and Germans differ in their perceptions of the world’s leading economic power](image4)

When it comes to the EU, Germans are far more favorable, with roughly seven-in-ten expressing support, while only about half of Americans agree. This divide reflects broader ideological differences, as liberals and those on the left in both countries tend to favor the EU more than conservatives and those on the right [8]. ![Germans view the EU more positively than Americans](image1)

Relations with China also diverge, with Germans more likely to see it as the leading economic power and Americans more divided. Despite these differences, cooperation trends show a shift: 69% of Americans want increased cooperation with Germany, while only half of Germans reciprocate this sentiment toward the U.S., though this percentage has risen since 2018 [3].

In summary, Americans and Germans differ significantly in their perceptions of the leading economic power and their relationships with the EU and China, with Germans leaning more favorably toward China and the EU, while Americans prioritize their own country’s economic dominance.

Americans and Germans hold differing views on international organizations and economic powers, influenced by ideological, geographic, and historical factors. 

![Views of international organizations and economic powers vary between Americans and Germans.](image1)  
Germans generally view international organizations like the UN, EU, and NATO more positively than Americans. For instance, 71% of Germans favor the EU, compared to only 51% of Americans [1][10]. Similarly, Germans are more likely to have a favorable view of the UN and NATO, though the gap is narrower [10]. This divergence is partly due to ideological differences. In both countries, liberals and those on the left are more supportive of the UN and EU than conservatives and those on the right. However, these ideological divides are more pronounced among Americans [3][9]. 

![Germans are more likely to name China as the world’s leading economic power.](image2)  
When it comes to economic powers, 53% of Germans name China as the leading global economic power, while only 32% of Americans agree. In contrast, half of Americans see the U.S. as the top economic power, compared to just 24% of Germans [7][8]. These differences may stem from varying perceptions of global economic dynamics and leadership.  

![Regional and generational factors also shape views of economic powers.](image3)  
Geographic and generational factors further influence these perceptions. Germans in former East Germany tend to view Russia more favorably and the EU less favorably than those in the former West [5]. Additionally, younger Germans (18-29) are more likely to see China as the leading economic power (58%), while older Germans (65+) are more likely to view the U.S. as dominant (53%) [10]. 

![Ideological differences significantly shape views of the UN, EU, and Russia.](image4)  
In summary, Americans and Germans differ in their views of international organizations and economic powers due to ideological divides, regional differences, and generational perspectives. These factors collectively shape their respective perceptions of global leadership and cooperation.

Americans and Germans hold differing views on the necessity of military force and defense spending. About eight-in-ten Americans believe it is sometimes necessary to use military force to maintain global order, whereas only about half of Germans share this view[4]. Additionally, ideological differences influence these perceptions. In the U.S., 90% of conservatives see military force as necessary, compared to 65% of liberals. Similarly, in Germany, nearly six-in-ten on the ideological right agree, while only about a third on the left do[6].

Regarding defense spending, half of Americans believe their European allies should maintain current spending levels, a shift from 2017 when 45% favored an increase[1][3]. Germans, on the other hand, are divided: about four-in-ten support increasing defense spending, and a similar proportion prefer maintaining current levels[5]. ![Germans are divided on whether to increase or maintain defense spending](image4)

When it comes to age demographics, younger generations in both countries view the U.S.-Germany relationship more positively. In the U.S., 82% of people aged 18 to 29 see the relationship as good, compared to 73% of those 65 and older. In Germany, 40% of young people hold this view, while only 31% of older Germans do[2][8]. ![Younger generations in the U.S. and Germany have a more positive view of bilateral relations](image5)

In summary, Americans are more supportive of using military force and have mixed views on European defense spending, while Germans are divided on defense spending and less likely to justify military force. Younger populations in both countries are more optimistic about U.S.-Germany relations.

Americans and Germans hold contrasting views on military intervention and defense spending, reflecting broader differences in their national security perspectives. When it comes to defending NATO allies against potential Russian aggression, six-in-ten Americans believe their country should use military force, while an equal share of Germans oppose such action [9]. This divergence is further highlighted in attitudes toward the use of military force generally, with about eight-in-ten Americans viewing it as sometimes necessary, compared to only half of Germans [6]. ![Graph showing U.S. and German views on using military force to defend a NATO ally against Russia](image1)

On defense spending, Americans and Germans also differ significantly. Half of Americans believe their European allies should maintain current defense spending levels, marking a shift from 2017 when 45% favored increased spending [2]. In contrast, Germans are divided, with about four-in-ten supporting increased spending and an equal share favoring maintaining current levels [10]. ![Chart comparing U.S. and German opinions on defense spending for European allies and Germany](image4)

Additionally, Americans place higher importance on U.S. military bases in Germany, with 85% seeing them as important to U.S. security, compared to only about half of Germans who view them as crucial for German security [3] [5]. Ideological divides also play a role, as conservatives in both countries are more likely than liberals to support the use of military force and increased defense spending [4] [7]. ![Graph illustrating U.S. partisan views on defense spending in Europe from 2017 to 2019](image5)

In summary, Americans are more inclined toward military intervention and see greater importance in maintaining military bases abroad, while Germans are more skeptical of such measures and divided on defense spending priorities.

American and German opinions on defense spending have evolved since 2017, with notable partisan differences in both countries. In the U.S., the share of Americans who believe their European allies should increase defense spending has declined. In 2017, 45% of Americans supported this view, but by 2019, only half of Americans favored maintaining current levels, marking a shift toward stability [5]. This trend is partly driven by partisan divides: Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more likely to support increased defense spending in Europe compared to Democrats, though support among Republicans has fallen by 14 percentage points from 2017 to 2019 [8]. ![U.S. opinion trends on European defense spending](image2)  

In Germany, public opinion on defense spending has also shifted. In 2017, about half of Germans were content with their country’s defense spending, while a third favored increases. By 2019, Germans were evenly split, with about four-in-ten supporting either increasing or maintaining spending [7]. Partisan differences are evident here as well: CDU/CSU supporters are more likely to favor defense spending increases, while Greens are more skeptical, with only 28% supporting raises. SPD members fall in the middle at 41% [1]. ![German partisan views on defense spending](image1)  

Both countries also differ on the importance of U.S. military bases in Germany. While 85% of Americans see these bases as important to U.S. security, Germans are divided, with about half considering them important for German security and 45% disagreeing [6][9]. ![German views on U.S. military bases](image3)  

In summary, Americans have shifted toward preferring stable European defense spending, while Germans are split on whether to increase or maintain their own spending, with significant partisan divides in both countries.

From 2017 to 2019, American and German views on national defense spending showed notable shifts and partisan divides. In the U.S., Republican-leaning individuals were more likely than Democrats to favor increased defense spending in Europe, but their support for this view declined by 14 percentage points over this period. A smaller decline was also observed among Democrats [3]. Meanwhile, by 2019, half of Americans believed European allies should maintain current defense spending levels, a significant change from 2017, when 45% advocated for increases [4]. 

![Americans increasingly support maintaining current defense spending levels](image1)  

In Germany, public opinion was divided, with about four-in-ten favoring increased defense spending and a similar share advocating for maintaining current levels. This marked a shift from 2017, when about half of Germans were content with spending levels and a third supported increases [10]. Partisan differences were evident in Germany as well, with supporters of the CDU/CSU more likely to favor increased spending, while only 28% of Green Party supporters shared this view [9]. 

![Germans are divided on whether to increase or maintain defense spending](image1)  

Additionally, generational differences in Germany influenced perceptions of U.S. military presence, with younger Germans (ages 18-29) more likely to doubt the importance of U.S. bases for national security compared to older Germans (65+), of whom 61% viewed the bases as important [8]. 

![Younger Germans doubt the importance of U.S. military bases for security](image4)  

In summary, American views shifted toward maintaining European defense spending, while Germans remained divided on increasing or maintaining their own defense budgets, with clear partisan and generational divides in both countries.

In the U.S., political affiliations significantly shape views on increasing defense spending. Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more likely than Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents to favor increased defense spending in Europe. However, the share of Republicans who think it is important for European allies to increase their defense budgets declined by 14 percentage points between 2017 and 2019 [3]. Democrats also saw a modest decline in this view [3]. ![U.S. partisan opinions on European defense spending over time](image5)

In Germany, partisan gaps are evident as well. Supporters of the CDU/CSU tend to favor increased defense spending, while only 28% of Green Party supporters agree. SPD supporters fall in the middle, with 41% supporting higher defense spending [5]. ![German partisan opinions on increasing defense spending](image1)

Over time, opinions on the importance of U.S. military bases in Germany have shown generational divides. Younger Germans (ages 18–29) are more skeptical, with 62% believing these bases do not contribute to national security, compared to 61% of those 65 and older who see them as important [6]. ![Generational divide in Germany on the importance of U.S. military bases](image4)

Overall, political affiliations in both countries significantly influence opinions on defense spending, with partisan divides in both the U.S. and Germany, and shifts in U.S. attitudes toward European defense budgets over time.

In Germany, age significantly influences perceptions of the importance of U.S. military bases. Younger Germans, particularly those aged 18 to 29, are more skeptical, with roughly six-in-ten believing these bases do not contribute to German national security. In contrast, 61% of Germans aged 65 and older view the bases as important to their country’s defense [9]. ![Younger Germans are more skeptical of U.S. military bases' importance](image5).

In the U.S., political affiliation shapes views on foreign policy partners and the importance of U.S. military bases in Germany. Both Democrats and Republicans rank Germany similarly as a foreign policy partner, placing it fifth on their lists [4][7]. However, Republicans are more likely to prioritize Israel as a key partner compared to Democrats [4]. When it comes to the U.S. military presence in Germany, support is high among both parties, though Republicans express slightly stronger backing than Democrats [10]. ![Republicans and Democrats similarly rank Germany as a foreign policy partner](image4).

Overall, age differences in Germany create a split in views on U.S. military bases, while political affiliations in the U.S. influence foreign policy priorities but show broad agreement on the importance of maintaining a military presence in Germany.

Views on U.S. global engagement and handling of international issues vary significantly across political affiliations and educational backgrounds.  

Among political affiliations, **Republicans** largely favor a focus on domestic issues rather than assisting other countries. About three-quarters of Republicans believe the U.S. should deal with its own problems and let other nations manage as best they can [5]. This view is consistent across both conservative and more moderate or liberal Republicans [5]. Conversely, **Democrats** are more divided. While 46% of Democrats prioritize domestic issues, a majority (54%) support helping other countries with their problems [8]. This divide is further influenced by ideology, with 64% of liberal Democrats favoring global assistance compared to 44% of conservative and moderate Democrats [8].  

Educational background also plays a role in shaping these opinions. Those with higher levels of education, such as **postgraduates**, are more supportive of U.S. engagement in assisting other nations, with 60% in favor [10]. College graduates are evenly split on the issue, while majorities of those with **some college experience** or a **high school diploma or less** believe the U.S. should prioritize its own problems [10].  

![U.S. views on global engagement vary by education level](image3)  
![Political affiliations influence opinions on global engagement](image4)  

In summary, Republicans and less-educated individuals tend to prioritize domestic issues, while Democrats, particularly liberal ones, and those with higher education levels are more supportive of U.S. global engagement.

Political affiliations and educational backgrounds significantly shape Americans' perceptions of how the U.S. and China have handled the COVID-19 pandemic. 

Regarding the U.S., opinions are sharply divided along party lines. Around 73% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents are critical of the U.S. response, while 71% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents praise it [3]. This partisan divide is further emphasized in the data, where only 27% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents believe the U.S. has done a good or excellent job, compared to 71% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents [10]. ![Wide partisan gap on U.S. response](image2)

Education also plays a role in shaping views of the U.S. response. Around two-thirds of those with a postgraduate degree and six-in-ten college graduates say the U.S. has done a poor job, compared to 43% of those with a high school degree or less [2]. ![Education’s influence on U.S. response](image3)

When it comes to China’s handling of the pandemic, education has minimal influence. Majorities in all educational groups say China has not handled the pandemic well, with nearly two-thirds of Americans overall expressing criticism [4][6]. Age also plays a role, with older Americans (69% of those 65 and older) being more critical than younger Americans (59% of those under 30) [7]. ![Critical views of China’s response](image5)

In summary, political affiliation drives stark differences in perceptions of the U.S. response, while education amplifies criticism among more educated Americans. For China, criticism is widespread across all groups, with age influencing the intensity of disapproval.

Political affiliations significantly influence how Americans perceive the handling of the COVID-19 pandemic in both the U.S. and China. When it comes to the U.S. response, there is a stark partisan divide. Only 27% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents believe the U.S. has done a good or excellent job, compared to 71% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents [8]. This gap is evident in evaluations of the U.S.’s ability to learn from other countries, with those who think the U.S. can learn from abroad being less positive about its handling of the pandemic (44%) compared to those who don’t (63%) [5]. 

![U.S. handling of COVID-19 viewed less positively by those who think it can learn from other countries](image1)

Regarding China, while majorities across both parties criticize its handling of the pandemic, Republicans are more likely to hold this view than Democrats. For example, 80% of conservative Republicans say China has not handled the crisis well, compared to a smaller share of Democrats [9]. Partisan differences are also evident in evaluations of other countries, though the gaps are smaller. For instance, 54% of Republicans believe the UK has done an excellent or good job, compared to 45% of Democrats [4].

![Republicans are more critical of China's COVID-19 response than Democrats](image2)

Overall, political affiliations shape perceptions of pandemic responses, with Republicans being more approving of the U.S. and more critical of China, while Democrats tend to be more critical of the U.S. and slightly less harsh on China.

Perceptions of the U.S.'s ability to learn from other countries in handling the coronavirus vary significantly along political lines. While 67% of liberal Democrats believe the U.S. can learn a great deal from other nations, only 25% of conservative Republicans share this view [5]. Similarly, 60% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents think the U.S. can learn a great deal from the international response, compared to just 28% of Republicans and Republican leaners [6]. Those who believe the U.S. can learn from other countries are also more likely to think other nations are handling the outbreak well [7][8].

Trust in international organizations like the WHO and EU also reflects partisan divides. Liberal Democrats overwhelmingly trust the WHO (86%) and the EU (79%), while conservative Republicans have far lower levels of trust in the WHO (27%) and the EU (49%) [10]. ![Trust in WHO and EU varies significantly by political affiliation, with liberal Democrats expressing the highest trust levels](image1). Similarly, 62% of Democrats say the WHO has done at least a good job handling the pandemic, compared to only 28% of Republicans [9]. ![Democrats are more likely to trust and positively evaluate the WHO's handling of the pandemic than Republicans](image3).

Overall, political affiliation strongly influences both perceptions of the U.S.'s ability to learn from other countries and trust in international organizations, with Democrats generally more open to international collaboration and information.

Views about the future influence of the U.S., EU, and China after the coronavirus outbreak vary significantly based on political affiliation and education level.  

Regarding the **U.S.**, there is a clear partisan divide: Republicans are about twice as likely as Democrats to believe the U.S.’s international influence will strengthen, with 48% of Republicans holding this view compared to only 25% of Democrats [3]. Conversely, Democrats are four times more likely than Republicans to expect U.S. influence to weaken (34% vs. 8%) [3]. Additionally, education plays a role: 45% of Americans with postgraduate education believe the U.S.’s global influence will decline, compared to 37% of those with a high school education or less [10].  

When it comes to **China**, half of Americans believe its influence will decline, but this view is more prevalent among Republicans (63%) than Democrats (40%) [1]. Older Americans (65+) are also more likely to expect a decline in China’s influence compared to younger adults (18-29) [1].  

For the **EU**, while the data is less detailed, there is a general trend where Democrats and those with higher education levels are more likely to foresee a decline in EU influence. For example, 79% of liberal Democrats believe the EU will have less influence, compared to 67% of moderate/conservative Democrats [2].  

![Political affiliation significantly influences views on the future influence of the U.S., EU, and China](image2)  

In summary, political affiliation and education level shape divergent perspectives on the future global influence of the U.S., EU, and China, with Republicans and less educated individuals more optimistic about U.S. influence, while Democrats and more educated individuals expect declines across the board.

Predictions about the global influence of the U.S. and China after the coronavirus outbreak vary significantly across demographic and political lines.  

For the U.S., there is a clear partisan divide. Republicans are about twice as likely as Democrats to believe the U.S.’s international influence will strengthen, while Democrats are about four times more likely than Republicans to expect it to weaken [1]. Among Democrats, liberal supporters are 20 percentage points more likely than conservatives and moderates within the party to foresee a decline in U.S. influence [1]. Education also plays a role, with Americans who have completed higher levels of education more likely to think the country’s global influence will recede [9]. ![More About the Less](image1)  

When it comes to China, half of Americans believe its international influence will decline after the outbreak, with Republicans (roughly six-in-ten) more likely than Democrats (40%) to hold this view [4]. Older Americans (65+) are 16 percentage points more likely than those under 30 to say China will have less global influence [4]. These partisan and age divides align with broader negative attitudes toward China, particularly among older Americans and Republicans [7]. ![More About the Less](image4)  

Overall, the data highlights how partisan affiliation, age, and education shape perceptions of the U.S. and China’s global influence post-pandemic.

Americans generally hold negative views of China’s handling of the coronavirus outbreak. Nearly two-thirds of Americans say China has not done a good job dealing with the crisis, with 37% stating it has done a poor job [3]. These perceptions are further highlighted by the fact that few trust coronavirus information from the Chinese government, despite a belief that China has handled the outbreak well [1]. 

When it comes to China’s future influence in world affairs, there is a divided outlook. Half of Americans believe China’s global influence will decline after the outbreak, while nearly one-in-five think it will grow, and about a third expect it to remain the same [2]. ![Half of Americans believe China's global influence will decline](image3). This uncertainty is also reflected in a broader context where many believe the pandemic will have a long-term impact on China’s global stature, with 50% saying China will have less influence in world affairs [9].

Partisan differences significantly shape these perceptions. Republicans are more critical of China’s handling of the outbreak, with 80% of conservative Republicans saying China has not done a good job, compared to a smaller majority of Democrats [7]. ![Republicans are more critical of China's handling](image5). Similarly, Republicans are more likely to believe China’s international clout will diminish (roughly six-in-ten) compared to just 40% of Democrats [5]. Age also plays a role, with older Americans more likely to believe China’s influence will decline [5].

These partisan divides extend to broader views on international affairs. For example, Republicans and Democrats differ sharply in their trust of the World Health Organization (WHO), with 80% of Democrats trusting its coronavirus information compared to only 36% of Republicans [6]. ![Democrats trust the WHO more than Republicans](image1). Such differences underscore how perceptions of China and global institutions are deeply influenced by political affiliation.

Partisan views on the U.S. role in solving world problems and its influence after the coronavirus outbreak reveal significant differences between Republicans and Democrats, as well as shifts in attitudes over time from 2013 to 2020.  

![62% of Republicans believe the U.S. does too much in addressing global challenges](image1)  
In 2020, about 62% of Republicans thought the U.S. does too much in helping address global challenges, compared to just 26% of Democrats. This partisan gap has widened since 2013, when the divide was more modest [5].  

![Republicans are more likely to believe the U.S.’s international influence will strengthen after the crisis](image2)  
Republicans are about twice as likely as Democrats to believe the U.S. will emerge from the crisis with stronger international influence. Conversely, Democrats are four times more likely than Republicans to expect U.S. influence to weaken. Liberal Democrats are particularly pessimistic, with 56% foreseeing a decline in U.S. global influence, compared to just 8% of conservative Republicans [7][10].  

![There is a stark partisan divide in how the U.S. is viewed in dealing with the coronavirus outbreak](image2)  
Republicans and Democrats also differ in their assessment of the U.S. response to COVID-19. While 81% of liberal Democrats think the U.S. has done an only fair or poor job in handling the outbreak, only 22% of conservative Republicans agree [7].  

![The trend from 2013 to 2020 shows a growing partisan divide on whether the U.S. does too much or too little in solving global problems](image5)  
From 2013 to 2020, the share of Republicans who believe the U.S. does too much in addressing global challenges increased significantly, while Democrats’ views remained more stable. This underscores a deepening partisan divide over America’s international role [5][6].  

![Democrats are more likely than Republicans to believe the U.S. can learn from other countries about combating COVID-19](image4)  
On issues like learning from other countries to combat COVID-19, 60% of Democrats believe the U.S. can learn a great deal, compared to just 28% of Republicans. This highlights a broader partisan split in attitudes toward international collaboration [4][8].  

In summary, partisan differences have grown significantly from 2013 to 2020, with Republicans increasingly skeptical of U.S. involvement in global problems and more optimistic about its influence post-COVID-19, while Democrats are more critical of the U.S. response and foresee a decline in its global standing.

Partisan views on the U.S.’s ability to learn from other countries and its role in global affairs during the coronavirus pandemic are sharply divided, particularly along ideological lines. 

![A majority of Democrats believe the U.S. can learn a great deal from other countries, while Republicans are less optimistic.](image5)  

Liberal Democrats are significantly more likely to believe the U.S. can learn a great deal from other nations about combating COVID-19, with 67% holding this view compared to only 25% of conservative Republicans. Similarly, 60% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents say the U.S. can learn a great deal, while just 28% of Republicans and Republican leaners share this opinion [4][8].  

![Democrats are more critical of the U.S. response to the pandemic and its global influence.](image5)  

Partisanship also influences perceptions of the U.S.’s role in global affairs. Liberal Democrats are more critical of the U.S. response to the pandemic, with 81% saying the country has done an only fair or poor job, compared to just 22% of conservative Republicans. Additionally, 56% of liberal Democrats believe the U.S. will have less influence in world affairs after the pandemic, a view shared by only 8% of conservative Republicans [6].  

![Education levels further divide opinions on the U.S.’s ability to learn from other countries.](image1)  

Education plays a role in these partisan divides, with those holding higher levels of education more likely to believe the U.S. can learn from other countries [2][9]. For instance, 56% of postgraduates say the U.S. can learn a great deal, compared to 44% of those with a high school education or less [image1].  

In summary, partisan views on the U.S.’s ability to learn from other countries and its global role during the pandemic differ significantly, with Democrats and those with higher education levels more likely to value international collaboration and critique the U.S. response.

Views on whether the U.S. should deal with its own problems versus helping other countries vary significantly across political affiliations and educational levels. According to [2], 60% of Americans believe the U.S. should focus on its own problems, while 39% think it should help other countries. This perspective is strongly influenced by political affiliation. For instance, 77% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents prefer the U.S. to handle its own issues, compared to only 27% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents [6]. Among Democrats, there is a further divide by ideology: 64% of liberal Democrats support helping other countries, while only 44% of conservative and moderate Democrats share this view [4]. 

Educational levels also play a role in shaping these attitudes. Postgraduates are more supportive of aiding other nations, with 60% advocating for such assistance, whereas only 29% of those with a high school diploma or less share this perspective [9]. ![Educational levels influence attitudes toward helping other nations](image5). These findings highlight the interplay between political ideology and education in shaping perceptions of America’s role in global issues.

Perceptions of the U.S. role in solving world problems vary significantly by political affiliation, with Republicans and Democrats holding contrasting views. Currently, 62% of Republicans believe the U.S. does too much to help solve world problems, while only 8% think it does too little and 29% say it does the right amount [3]. In contrast, a plurality of Democrats (48%) say the U.S. does too little, with 26% each believing it does too much or the right amount [3]. These views have become more polarized over time, as the partisan divide was far less pronounced in previous years [6].

![Republicans and Democrats differ on whether the U.S. does too much or too little to solve world problems.](image1)

Historical data shows that in 2013, 37% of Republicans thought the U.S. did too much, compared to 52% in 2020 [image3]. Among Democrats, 21% in 2013 believed the U.S. did too little, rising to 37% in 2020 [image5]. This indicates a widening gap in perceptions between the two groups.

![Trends over time show increasing polarization in views on U.S. involvement in global problems.](image3)
![Democrats' view of the U.S. role in global problems has shifted toward doing too little.](image5)

Additionally, when it comes to whether the U.S. should help other countries deal with their problems, 60% of the overall population believes the U.S. should focus on its own problems [5]. However, this view is more pronounced among Republicans, with about 75% holding this opinion, compared to 46% of Democrats [7][8]. 

![Partisan differences are evident in views on whether the U.S. should help other countries.](image2)

In summary, Republicans increasingly see the U.S. as doing too much to solve global problems and prefer a focus on domestic issues, while Democrats are more likely to believe the U.S. should take a more active role internationally. These differences have grown more pronounced over time.

Views on U.S. global engagement and domestic priorities vary significantly by political affiliation and educational attainment. 

- **Political Affiliation**:
  - **Republicans**: A majority of Republicans (62%) believe the U.S. does too much to help solve world problems, with 77% preferring the U.S. focus on its own issues rather than aiding other countries. Conservative Republicans are particularly strong in this view, with 81% supporting a domestic focus. Only 8% of Republicans think the U.S. does too little globally [3, 10].  
  - **Democrats**: In contrast, 48% of Democrats say the U.S. does too little to address global problems, and 64% of liberal Democrats advocate for helping other nations. However, 46% of Democrats still prioritize domestic issues over international aid, reflecting internal ideological divides [3, 5].

- **Educational Attainment**:
  - Higher education correlates with support for global engagement. Six-in-ten postgraduates believe the U.S. should assist other countries, while those with only a high school education or less are more likely to prioritize domestic issues [6]. More educated Americans are also more critical of the U.S. pandemic response, with 66% of postgraduates saying the U.S. has done a poor job [9].

Images further illustrate these trends:  
![Republicans overwhelmingly prioritize domestic issues over global engagement](image1)  
![Support for global engagement increases with higher educational attainment](image4)  

In summary, Republicans and less-educated individuals favor focusing on domestic issues, while Democrats and more-educated Americans are more supportive of U.S. global engagement.

Americans have mixed confidence in President Biden’s ability to deal effectively with China, with only 53% expressing confidence—the lowest among six foreign policy issues tested [2]. In contrast, specific concerns related to China are viewed as highly serious, with cyberattacks from China and China’s growing military power being described as "very serious" by 52% and 49% of Americans, respectively [10]. ![Americans express significant concern about cyberattacks and military power](image4)

Partisan differences further highlight this disparity, as 83% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning individuals express confidence in Biden on China, compared to just 19% of Republicans and Republican-leaning individuals [4]. This contrasts with the widespread bipartisan concern about issues like cyberattacks and military power, which are seen as at least somewhat serious by over 75% of Americans [10]. ![Partisan divides in confidence levels regarding Biden’s handling of China](image3)

Additionally, while Biden receives higher confidence ratings for other foreign policy issues, such as improving relationships with allies (67%) and dealing with global climate change (60%), these areas are not as directly tied to China-specific concerns [2]. ![Confidence levels in Biden across various foreign policy issues](image1)

In summary, Americans are more uniformly concerned about China-related issues like cyberattacks and military power than they are confident in Biden’s ability to handle China effectively.

Americans' confidence in President Biden to deal effectively with China varies significantly across demographic groups. **Women** (59%) express more confidence than **men** (48%) [10]. **Black** (82%) and **Hispanic adults** (70%) are notably more confident than **White adults** (43%) [10]. Additionally, individuals with a **college degree** (60%) are more confident than those without one (50%) [10]. Partisan differences are stark: **83% of Democrats and Democratic leaners** have confidence in Biden on China, compared to just **19% of Republicans and Republican leaners**. Among Republicans, **conservatives** (10%) have the least confidence, while **moderate or liberal Republicans** (30%) show slightly more [3].

![Demographic breakdown of confidence in Biden to deal with China](image2)

The **primary concerns Americans have regarding China** include **cyberattacks from China**, the **loss of U.S. jobs to China**, **China’s growing military power**, and **China’s policies on human rights**. These issues are described as **very serious** by about half or more of Americans [5]. Other concerns include the **U.S. trade deficit with China** and **tensions between mainland China and Hong Kong or Taiwan**, though these are seen as less severe overall [1][6]. 

![Americans' concerns about China, ranked by seriousness](image3)

In summary, confidence in Biden to manage China-related issues varies widely by gender, race, education, and political affiliation, while cyberattacks, job losses, military power, and human rights are the most pressing concerns about China.

Confidence in President Biden’s ability to deal effectively with China varies significantly across demographic and political groups. Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents express much higher confidence (83%) compared to only 19% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents [3][4]. ![Democrats are significantly more confident in Biden than Republicans](image1). Among Republicans, conservative Republicans show even less confidence (10%) than moderate or liberal Republicans (30%) [4]. Women (59%) are more confident than men (48%), and Black (82%) and Hispanic adults (70%) express more confidence than White adults (43%) [6]. Additionally, those with a college degree (60%) are more likely to have confidence in Biden compared to those with less education (50%) [6]. ![Confidence in Biden varies by gender, race, and education level](image3).

When it comes to concerns about China, specific issues are viewed as very serious by a majority of Americans. Cyberattacks from China, the loss of U.S. jobs to China, China’s growing military power, and China’s policies on human rights are the top concerns, with over half of Americans describing these as very serious [5][9]. ![Top concerns about China include cyberattacks, job losses, and military power](image4). The share of Americans who see the loss of U.S. jobs to China as a very serious problem has increased by 6 points since 2020, reaching 53% [7]. Similarly, concerns about China’s policies on human rights have risen by 7 percentage points since last year, with half of Americans now viewing this as a very serious issue [9].

Partisanship also plays a significant role in how these concerns are perceived, with Republicans generally viewing these issues as more serious than Democrats [2]. ![Partisan differences in assessing the seriousness of China-related issues](image2). Overall, Americans express substantial concern about multiple aspects of the U.S.-China relationship, with partisan and demographic divides shaping both confidence in leadership and perceptions of key issues.

Confidence in President Joe Biden's ability to deal effectively with China varies significantly across demographic and partisan lines. Democrats and those leaning Democratic are much more confident in Biden's approach, with 83% expressing confidence. In contrast, only 19% of Republicans and their leaners share this sentiment, with conservative Republicans being the least confident at 10% [3]. ![Confidence levels across demographic groups](image1)

When it comes to concerns about China, Americans are particularly worried about cyberattacks, with 66% considering them a very serious problem, a 7-point increase since 2020 [7]. Other major concerns include the loss of U.S. jobs to China (53%, up 6 points since 2020), China’s growing military power (52%), and its human rights policies (50%) [8][10]. Older Americans, especially those aged 65 and older, express more concern about these issues compared to younger adults [6]. ![Concerns about China's impact on the U.S.](image2)

Additionally, partisan differences are evident in the level of concern. Republicans, especially conservative Republicans, have seen greater increases in concern about issues like the loss of U.S. jobs to China compared to Democrats [9]. ![Partisan differences in concerns about China](image3)

In summary, confidence in Biden’s ability to handle China is high among Democrats but very low among Republicans, and Americans are most concerned about cyberattacks, job losses, China’s military power, and human rights policies.

Americans hold largely negative views of China’s handling of the COVID-19 pandemic, with 54% saying China has done a bad job and 28% describing it as very bad [7]. These perceptions vary by political affiliation, with 71% of Republicans and 39% of Democrats critical of China’s pandemic response. Educational background and race also influence these views, as those without a college degree and White Americans are more likely to criticize China’s handling [8]. 

![China's handling of COVID-19 is viewed negatively by 54% of Americans](image2)  

Similarly, Americans overwhelmingly believe that China does not respect the personal freedoms of its people, with 90% holding this view. This perspective is shared across age, education, and political groups [6]. The sense of China’s disregard for human rights has grown, with 50% of Americans now seeing it as a very serious problem for the U.S., up 7 percentage points from the previous year [2].

![90% of Americans believe China does not respect personal freedoms](image1)  

When it comes to U.S. priorities in its relationship with China, Americans are divided. Some believe the U.S. should prioritize economic relations even if it means not addressing human rights issues, while others argue for promoting human rights even if it harms economic relations [1]. 

![Americans are divided on prioritizing economic relations versus human rights in U.S.-China relations](image1)  

In summary, Americans are highly critical of China’s handling of COVID-19 and its respect for personal freedoms, and they are split on whether the U.S. should prioritize economic ties or human rights in its relations with China.

When it comes to the balance between promoting human rights and economic relations with China, political affiliations in the U.S. show distinct perspectives. Among Republicans and Republican-leaning independents, there is a strong preference for prioritizing human rights over economic ties. About 70% of Republicans advocate for promoting human rights in China, even if it harms economic relations, with conservative Republicans being particularly adamant at 81% [6]. ![Conservative Republicans emphasize human rights over economic ties](image3)

Democrats and Democrat-leaning independents also generally favor human rights, with about 70% supporting this stance. However, there is a notable divide within the Democratic base: liberal Democrats are the most likely to prioritize human rights (70%), while more moderate or conservative Democrats express a similar but slightly less pronounced preference [6]. ![Liberal Democrats prioritize human rights over economic relations](image5)

Interestingly, the desire for the U.S. to get tougher on China in trade policies is more prevalent among Republicans (72%) and especially conservative Republicans (81%). In contrast, about 60% of Democrats and Democrat-leaning independents prefer focusing on building stronger economic ties with China, a sentiment consistent across liberal and moderate/conservative Democrats [9]. ![Republicans prefer tougher trade policies, while Democrats favor stronger economic ties](image2)

Overall, both major political groups lean toward prioritizing human rights, but Republicans, particularly conservatives, are more inclined to adopt a tougher stance on China, whereas Democrats emphasize building a stronger economic relationship. ![Americans generally prioritize human rights over economic ties with China](image4)

Americans generally prioritize promoting human rights in China over maintaining strong economic ties, with 70% favoring human rights even if it harms economic relations. This sentiment is shared across party lines, with about seven-in-ten Democrats and Republicans holding this view. Among Republicans, conservative Republicans are more likely to emphasize human rights compared to their moderate or liberal counterparts. Similarly, liberal Democrats are the most likely to prioritize human rights over economic dealings in U.S.-China relations [7][10]. 

![Prioritizing human rights over economic relations is a bipartisan stance](image1)

When it comes to trade policies, opinions diverge more sharply along party lines. Republicans and Republican-leaning independents overwhelmingly want the U.S. to get tougher with China, with 72% holding this view, and conservative Republicans even more so at 81%. In contrast, about six-in-ten Democrats and Democrat-leaning independents prefer focusing on building stronger ties with China. This divide reflects a broader partisan split in how economic and trade policies with China are perceived [6].

![Republicans are more likely to favor a tougher stance on China trade issues](image5)

In summary, while there is broad bipartisan support for prioritizing human rights over economic relations with China, Republicans and Democrats differ significantly on whether the U.S. should adopt a tougher stance on trade issues, with Republicans favoring a more confrontational approach and Democrats leaning toward strengthening ties.

When it comes to U.S. trade policies with China, political affiliations significantly shape opinions and preferences. Republicans and Republican-leaning independents overwhelmingly favor a tougher stance on China, with 72% advocating for this approach, and conservative Republicans being the most emphatic at 81% [1]. This aligns with their broader support for tariffs, as about half of Republicans believe increased tariffs on Chinese and foreign products were good for the U.S., particularly among conservative Republicans [2]. In contrast, Democrats and Democrat-leaning independents prefer building stronger ties with China, with about six-in-ten supporting this approach [1], and they are more critical of tariffs, with most saying they were bad for the U.S. [2].

![Political affiliations and views on trade policies with China](image1)  
This image illustrates the differing perspectives across political groups, showing a clear divide between Republicans and Democrats on whether to get tougher with China or focus on building stronger relationships.

The partisan divide is further highlighted when examining views on the economic relationship between the U.S. and China. A majority of Americans (64%) see current economic relations as bad, but this sentiment varies by party affiliation [6]. Younger Americans, particularly those aged 18-29, are more likely to emphasize stronger relationships with China, regardless of political leaning [10].

![Impact of tariffs on the U.S. by political affiliation](image5)  
The image reinforces the partisan split, showing varying percentages of Republicans and Democrats who view tariffs as good or bad for the U.S., with Republicans more supportive and Democrats more critical.

In summary, Republicans generally favor a tougher approach and support tariffs, while Democrats prefer stronger relationships and are skeptical of tariffs. These differences reflect broader ideological and policy preferences within each political group.

Republicans and Democrats hold notably different views on the impacts of tariffs and international students in the U.S. Republicans tend to see tariffs on Chinese and other foreign goods as having a positive effect for the country, with about half describing increased tariffs as good for the U.S., especially among conservative Republicans [1][10]. On the other hand, Democrats predominantly view the tariffs negatively, with most saying they were bad for the U.S. [10]. This partisan divide is further emphasized when considering personal perceptions of the economy: those who believe the U.S. economy is in good shape are more likely to see tariffs as beneficial, a sentiment that aligns more closely with Republican perspectives [4].

![Republicans and Democrats differ in their views on tariffs](image3)

When it comes to international students, the U.S. public generally views them positively, with 80% saying it is good for U.S. colleges and universities to accept them [7]. However, partisanship influences these views as well. While both Democrats and Republicans see international students in a positive light, Democrats are significantly more supportive, with 92% holding this perspective compared to 67% of Republicans [2]. Specifically, support for limiting Chinese students studying in the U.S. shows a broader divide, with Republicans more likely to support restrictions (58%) compared to Democrats (35%) [5][8].

![Partisan differences in support for limiting Chinese students](image5)

In summary, Republicans are more likely to support tariffs and favor restrictions on Chinese students, while Democrats generally oppose tariffs and are more welcoming of international students, reflecting significant partisan differences on these issues.

Across age groups, older Americans are more likely to support limiting Chinese students in U.S. universities. Roughly seven-in-ten Americans aged 50 and older favor such restrictions, while those aged 30 to 49 are evenly split. In contrast, nearly two-thirds of Americans aged 18 to 29 oppose the idea [3]. ![Support for limiting Chinese students increases with age](image4).

Political affiliation also plays a significant role. Republicans are more likely than Democrats to support limiting the number of Chinese students [1]. Specifically, 58% of Republicans or those leaning Republican favor restrictions, compared to 35% of Democrats or those leaning Democratic [4]. ![Republicans are more likely than Democrats to support limits on Chinese students](image4).

This divide in opinions may relate to differing levels of confidence in the Chinese leadership. Older Americans and Republicans are more likely to have no confidence in Chinese President Xi Jinping [10]. For instance, 53% of those aged 65 and older say they have no confidence at all in Xi, compared to 35% of those aged 18 to 29 [10]. Similarly, Republicans are more distrustful of Xi, with half saying they have no confidence at all, while only a third of Democrats share this sentiment [5]. ![Older Americans and Republicans have lower confidence in Xi Jinping](image1).

In summary, older Americans and Republicans are more likely to support limiting Chinese students and have lower confidence in Chinese leadership, while younger Americans and Democrats are more opposed to such restrictions and slightly more confident in Xi Jinping.

American perceptions of China have grown significantly more negative from 2018 to 2021, driven by concerns over human rights, economic competition, and China’s growing global influence. In 2018, 46% of Americans felt "cold" toward China, but by 2021, this number rose to 67%—a 21-point increase. This shift is particularly pronounced among Republicans, with 62% now feeling "very cold" toward China, up 31 points since 2018, compared to a 21-point increase among Democrats [7][8].  

![Prioritize strengthening economic relations with China, even if it Try to promote human rights in means not addressing human China, even if it harms rights issues economic relations with China](image1)  

One major concern is China’s human rights record, especially regarding the Uyghurs in Xinjiang, which has been labeled a "genocide" by the U.S. government. Half of Americans now view China’s human rights policies as a very serious problem for the U.S., a 7-point increase since 2020 [1][6]. Additionally, 20% of Americans cite human rights concerns as the first thing that comes to mind when thinking about China, with 3% specifically mentioning the Uyghurs [10].  

![Human rights Lack of freedoms Genocide, Uyghurs Economy "Made in China," manufacturing Bad products, knockoffs High growth rate Political system Dictatorship Communism/CCP Threats China wants to be the most powerful country U.S.-China relationship China hurts the U.S. economy General threat to the U.S. Generally negative adjectives COVID-19 Population size Generally positive adjectives Pollution Biden People](image3)  

Economic concerns also play a significant role. Nearly half of Americans (48%) believe limiting China’s power and influence should be a top foreign policy priority, up 16 points since 2018. Specific worries include job losses to China, cyber attacks, and China’s growing technological power [4][6]. Around 64% of Americans describe U.S.-China economic relations as somewhat or very bad, highlighting the fraught nature of the relationship [9].  

![% who... Say limiting China's power and influence is a 100% top priority 63: Rep/Lean Rep Total 48 Sic) 36 32 OO 26 Dem/Lean Dem 2018 2021 Feel "cold" toward China Rep/Lean Rep 79 Total GY ST 46 Dem/Lean Dem 38 2018 2021](image2)  

These trends reflect a broader shift in American attitudes, with human rights, economic competition, and geopolitical rivalry being the key drivers of increasingly negative perceptions of China.

Americans have several key concerns regarding China, many of which have intensified over time. **Human rights** and the **economy** are top of mind when Americans think of China, with many criticizing China's policies on human rights and its economic practices [2]. Specific concerns include **cyberattacks from China**, the **loss of U.S. jobs to China**, **China’s growing military power**, and **China’s policies on human rights**, all of which are described as very serious problems by a significant portion of Americans [9]. Over the past year, these concerns have grown, with half of Americans now viewing China’s human rights policy as a very serious problem, up 7 percentage points since last year [10].

![Concerns about China’s policies, including cyberattacks, human rights, job losses, and military power, have increased over time](image1)  

Additionally, Americans are critical of how China has handled global issues such as **climate change**, with 79% saying China is doing a bad job, and the **COVID-19 pandemic**, where 54% think China’s response has been poor [7][8]. Tensions over **China’s growing technological power**, **trade deficits**, and geopolitical conflicts, such as those between mainland China and Taiwan or Hong Kong, have also risen significantly [image1].  

Partisan divides further shape these concerns. Republicans are more likely to view China as an enemy, support tougher economic measures, and advocate for limiting Chinese students in the U.S. Democrats, while critical, are less likely to take such hardline stances [6].  

![Support for limiting China’s power and influence has grown, with Republicans more likely to feel "cold" toward China](image5)  

Overall, Americans see economic relations with China as fraught, with 64% describing them as somewhat or very bad, and confidence in President Biden’s ability to handle China effectively is lower than for other foreign policy issues [1][4][5]. These concerns reflect a broader perception of China as a growing threat to U.S. interests and values [10].

Since 2008, financial optimism among Hispanic subgroups has shown significant growth, often outpacing the general population. Latinos overall have become more optimistic, with 81% expecting their family’s financial situation to improve in the coming year, a 14 percentage point increase since 2008 [10]. ![Hispanic financial optimism rose to 81% in 2015](image5)

Education levels play a key role in this trend. Latinos with some college education saw a 20 percentage point increase in economic optimism, compared to those with a high school diploma (+9) or less education (+11) [2]. ![Education levels significantly influenced optimism changes](image1) Additionally, Americans with more education recovered faster from the Great Recession, which is reflected in Latinos’ financial expectations [5].

Age is another factor. Younger Latinos, particularly those under 30, have shown the most optimism, with a 13-point increase, while those aged 30-49 and 50-64 saw 16-point rises. Older Latinos (65+) had a smaller increase of 7 points [5]. ![Age groups demonstrated varying levels of optimism growth](image1) Across genders, Latino men (+18) and Latina women (+11) both reported increased optimism [6].

Compared to the general population, Latinos’ optimism has grown at a faster rate. While Latinos’ optimism rose by 14 points to 81%, the general population saw a 6-point increase to 61% [9]. ![Latinos’ optimism growth outpaced the general public](image5) 

In summary, from 2008 to 2015, financial optimism among Hispanic subgroups increased significantly, driven by education and age demographics, and consistently outpaced the general population’s growth in optimism.

Hispanic adults’ expectations for their children’s financial futures are influenced by their current financial situations and educational levels. Those who rate their current financial situation as positive are significantly more likely than those who rate it as fair or poor to believe their family’s finances will improve in the next 12 months [3]. This optimism extends to their children’s future, with 72% of Latino adults expecting their children to be better off financially than themselves [2]. ![Optimism about children's financial future is high among Hispanics](image5)

Educational attainment also plays a role, though the differences are nuanced. Among Latinos with at least some college experience, 69% expect their children to be better off financially, while 71% of those with less than a high school education share this view. Interestingly, high school graduates are the most optimistic, with 79% predicting their children will be better off [5]. ![Differences in optimism based on education levels](image3)

Additionally, age impacts these expectations. Younger Latinos (ages 18–29) are more optimistic (75%) compared to those 65 and older (52%), who are more pessimistic about their children’s financial futures [9]. ![Age-related differences in financial optimism](image5) Overall, those with better current financial conditions and higher educational attainment tend to be more optimistic about their children’s financial prospects.

The perceptions of financial well-being and unemployment trends among Latinos from 2000 to 2015 reveal a complex but gradually improving picture, despite persistent challenges.
