Median household income for Hispanics stagnated after the Great Recession, remaining at \$42,491 in 2014, nearly unchanged since the recession [1]. ![Median household income for Hispanics remained stagnant at \$42,500 in 2014 compared to \$53,700 for all households](image1) However, optimism about personal finances grew significantly during this period. In 2011, 67% of Latinos expected their finances to improve, a figure that rose to 81% by 2015 [2]. This increase in optimism outpaced that of the general public, which saw only a 6 percentage point rise during the same period [7]. ![General public’s optimism about family finances rose to 61% in 2015, while Latinos’ optimism surged to 81%](image3)

Unemployment trends also showed improvement but remained higher than pre-recession levels. The Latino unemployment rate peaked at 12.8% in 2010 during the Great Recession and declined to 6.4% by the end of 2015, though it was still above the 2006 low of 5% [6]. ![Hispanic unemployment rate declined to 6.4% in 2015 but remained higher than non-Hispanic workers](image5) Despite these challenges, 72% of Latino adults expressed optimism about their children's financial futures, believing they would be better off than themselves [3]. ![72% of Latinos expect their children to be better off financially than themselves, compared to 16% who expect no change and 5% who foresee a decline](image2)

In summary, while Latino perceptions of financial well-being improved significantly from 2000 to 2015, with rising optimism about personal and children's futures, unemployment rates remained higher than pre-recession levels, highlighting ongoing economic disparities.

The trends in unemployment rates and economic perceptions between Hispanic and non-Hispanic populations reveal both similarities and disparities. While both groups experienced a decline in unemployment rates since the Great Recession, Hispanic unemployment remains higher than that of non-Hispanic workers. For instance, the Hispanic unemployment rate fell from 12.8% in 2010 to 6.4% in late 2015, yet it stayed above the 5% low of 2006 and was higher than the non-Hispanic rate in the same period [6]. ![Trend in Hispanic unemployment rates compared to non-Hispanic workers](image5).

Despite these challenges, Hispanics are generally more optimistic about economic conditions. According to a 2015 survey, 35% of Hispanics described the economy as good or excellent, compared to 25% of whites, and 34% expected further improvement in the coming year [9]. This optimism is also reflected in their outlook for their children's financial future, with 72% believing their children will be better off financially than they are now [5]. ![Hispanic optimism about their children's financial future](image3).

However, income and wealth disparities persist. The median household income for Hispanics in 2014 was $42,491, significantly lower than the $53,700 for all households. Additionally, the Hispanic poverty rate stood at 23.6% in 2014, down from its peak of 26.5% in 2010 but still above pre-recession levels [3]. ![Disparities in median household income and poverty rates](image2).

These disparities are exacerbated by educational and economic factors. Hispanics with some college education or more (56%) and U.S.-born Hispanics (50%) were more likely to rate their personal finances as excellent or good, while those with less than a high school education (23%) and immigrant Hispanics (31%) were less likely to do so [4]. This suggests that education and nativity play critical roles in shaping economic outcomes.

Overall, while Hispanic unemployment rates are declining and their economic optimism remains high, income and wealth disparities persist, influenced by factors like education and immigration status. ![General economic trends across the general public and Hispanic population](image1).

Hispanic households have faced distinct economic challenges compared to all U.S. households from 2000 to 2015, particularly in unemployment, income, poverty rates, and wealth. 

![Quarterly unemployment rates for Hispanic and non-Hispanic workers show a decline but remain higher for Hispanics](image5) The unemployment rate for Hispanics improved from 12.8% in 2010 to 5.6% in 2016 but remained above the pre-recession low of 5% in 2006 and higher than the rate for non-Hispanic workers in 2015 [1]. 

![Median household income for Hispanics stagnated at $42,491 in 2014, lagging behind the general U.S. population](image2) Median household income for Hispanics stagnated at \$42,491 in 2014, unchanged since the Great Recession, while the general U.S. population also saw little income growth [7].

![Hispanic poverty rate declined from 26.5% in 2010 to 23.6% in 2014 but remained above pre-recession levels](image2) The Hispanic poverty rate decreased from a peak of 26.5% in 2010 to 23.6% in 2014, still higher than pre-recession levels, mirroring trends seen among all Americans [7].

![Hispanic households experienced the largest decline in net worth, falling below white households post-recession](image2) Hispanic households saw the largest percentage decline in net worth through 2009 and continued to lose wealth after the recession, unlike white households [7].

In summary, while Hispanic households have made some progress since the Great Recession, they continue to face greater economic challenges than the general U.S. population in unemployment, income stagnation, poverty rates, and wealth.

Between 2008 and 2015, perceptions of personal financial situations and family income relative to the cost of living improved significantly among Latino groups. In 2015, 48% of Latinos aged 18 to 29 reported being in excellent or good financial shape, a 27-point increase from 2008 [6]. Similarly, positive financial ratings rose by 17 percentage points among U.S.-born Hispanics and 18 points among foreign-born Hispanics [10]. ![Detailed breakdown of changes in financial perceptions among Latino subgroups from 2008 to 2015](image3)

Despite these gains, about half (53%) of Latinos in 2015 still felt their family income was not keeping up with the cost of living, a sentiment shared by whites and blacks [3]. However, this perception remained unchanged from 2014, indicating stability in this view over the short term [4]. ![Comparison of Hispanic, white, and black perceptions of family income relative to the cost of living in 2014 and 2015](image1)

Overall, Latino perceptions of economic well-being showed notable improvement compared to 2008, with most demographic subgroups recording double-digit gains in positive financial assessments [7][8]. ![Trends in positive financial views among Hispanics and the general public from 2004 to 2015](image2) ![Hispanic and general public views on financial conditions over time](image4)

Internet usage and device ownership among seniors vary significantly compared to the general adult population, with notable trends in their daily internet habits. 

![Seniors' internet usage declines sharply after age 75, especially in broadband adoption](image2) Seniors aged 65-69 have the highest rates of internet usage and broadband adoption, with 74% going online and 68% having broadband at home. However, these rates drop significantly after age 75, with only 37% of those aged 80+ using the internet and 21% having broadband at home [5][6]. This contrasts with younger adults, where internet usage remains consistently high across age groups [image1]. 

![Smartphone ownership is much lower among seniors compared to all adults](image3) Device ownership also differs, with only 43% of seniors owning a smartphone compared to 55% of all adults. Tablet or e-reader ownership is similar at 18% for both groups [2][image3]. 

![Most seniors who use the internet do so daily, with smartphone owners being the most frequent users](image1) Among seniors who use the internet, 71% go online daily or almost daily, and 11% do so 3-5 times per week. This frequency increases further for those with smartphones (84%) or broadband (78%) [4][8]. 

![Seniors who use social networking sites maintain stronger social connections](image4) Additionally, 27% of seniors use social networking sites like Facebook, and these users tend to have more persistent social connections compared to non-users [3][9]. 

In summary, while seniors show lower overall internet and device adoption rates compared to all adults, those who do use the internet integrate it deeply into their daily lives, especially if they own smartphones or broadband. Usage and adoption decline sharply after age 75.

The device ownership among older adults differs significantly from their internet usage patterns, with adoption levels of advanced technology lagging behind their engagement with online activities. While **59% of seniors report using the internet** [3], only **18% own a smartphone**, which is notably lower than the 55% ownership rate among all adults [5]. ![Smartphone ownership is significantly lower among older adults compared to the general population.](image4)

Interestingly, **tablets and e-book readers are equally popular as smartphones among older adults, with 18% ownership for each** [7]. This is distinct from the general population, where smartphones are far more common. Additionally, **27% of seniors own either a tablet, e-book reader, or both**, which is higher than the smartphone ownership rate in this group [7]. ![Tablets and e-readers are more commonly owned by older adults than smartphones.](image4)

Despite these lower device ownership rates, older adults who are internet users are highly engaged; **71% go online every day or almost every day**, and an additional **11% go online three to five times per week** [10]. ![Older adults who use the internet are highly engaged, with most going online daily.](image2)

In summary, while older adults have lower ownership rates of smartphones and other devices compared to the general population, their internet usage is frequent and consistent once they are online.

Device ownership and online activity differ significantly between seniors (aged 65+) and the general adult population. Only 18% of seniors own smartphones, compared to a national adoption rate of 55% [1]. Similarly, 27% of seniors own either a tablet or an e-book reader, whereas 43% of all adults own a tablet or e-book reader [3]. ![Smartphone and tablet/e-reader ownership rates](image3)

In terms of internet usage, 59% of seniors report using the internet, a sharp contrast to 86% of all U.S. adults [4]. Broadband adoption also lags among seniors, with 47% having broadband at home, compared to higher rates in the general population [1]. ![Internet adoption rates for seniors vs. all adults](image4)

However, there are notable trends in internet adoption over time. Senior internet usage has increased from 35% in 2008 to 59% in recent years, and broadband adoption has more than doubled from 19% to 46% over the same period [9]. ![Growth in internet adoption among seniors](image4)

Certain subgroups of seniors, such as those aged 65-69 or with higher education and income levels, show internet and broadband adoption rates closer to or even exceeding the general population [6]. For example, 74% of seniors aged 65-69 go online, and 87% of college-educated seniors use the internet [image1]. ![Internet and broadband usage by age, education, and income](image1)

Social networking site (SNS) usage is also lower among seniors, with 27% using platforms like Facebook, compared to higher rates in younger age groups [10]. ![Social networking site usage among seniors](image2)

Overall, while seniors are increasingly adopting digital technologies, they still trail the general adult population in device ownership and online activity, with significant disparities based on age, education, and income.

Device ownership and online social networking usage among seniors reveal interesting patterns. While 59% of seniors use the internet, only 27% of older adults use social networking sites (SNS) such as Facebook [2][7]. This suggests that while a significant portion of seniors are online, fewer engage with social media platforms.

![Seniors are equally likely to own smartphones, tablets, or e-book readers, with 18% owning each.](image1) Among older adults, ownership of tablets, e-book readers, and smartphones is identical at 18% [10]. Interestingly, the combined ownership of tablets or e-book readers (27%) exceeds smartphone ownership, indicating a preference for devices that may be more user-friendly or suited to their needs.

![Only 27% of seniors use social networking sites, while 41% do not go online at all.](image2) Social networking usage is lower among seniors compared to the general population. Only 27% of seniors use SNS, while 32% of online seniors do not use these platforms at all [4][7].

Demographic factors also play a role in device ownership and internet usage. For instance, younger, higher-income, and more educated seniors are more likely to use the internet and own devices like smartphones [3]. This is reflected in the data, where 35% of college graduates own smartphones, compared to just 10% of those with a high school education or less [3].

In summary, while device ownership among seniors is relatively balanced between smartphones, tablets, and e-book readers, their engagement with social networking sites remains limited, with only 27% using platforms like Facebook.

Among older adults, internet and broadband adoption rates vary significantly based on age, education, and income. Younger, higher-income, and more highly educated seniors show adoption rates approaching or even exceeding the general population, while older, lower-income, and less educated seniors lag behind[1][3][7][8].

![Internet usage among seniors increases with younger age, higher education, and income](image5)  
For example, 74% of seniors aged 65-69 go online, compared to just 37% of those aged 80 and older. Similarly, 87% of college graduates and 90% of seniors with household incomes of $75,000+ use the internet, while only 40% of those with a high school education or less and 39% of those earning under $30,000 do so[3][5][10]. Broadband adoption follows a similar trend, with 65% of 65-69-year-olds having broadband at home, dropping to 21% for those aged 80+[5].

![Smartphone adoption rates are significantly lower among older adults](image3)  
Smartphone adoption also reflects these disparities, with 29% of 65-69-year-olds using smartphones compared to 5% of those aged 80+. Higher education and income levels further boost adoption, with 35% of college graduates and 42% of seniors earning $75,000+ owning smartphones[4].

![Internet usage among seniors trails the general adult population](image4)  
Despite steady increases, senior internet usage (59%) and broadband adoption (47%) remain well below the general adult population rates of 86% and 70%, respectively[2][5]. In summary, internet and broadband adoption among older adults is higher among younger, wealthier, and more educated individuals, but overall rates still lag behind the general population.

Internet, broadband, cell phone, and smartphone adoption rates among seniors vary significantly based on income and education levels. 

**Income Levels**: 
- Seniors with an annual household income of $75,000 or more have the highest adoption rates, with 90% going online and 82% having broadband at home [9]. In contrast, only 39% of seniors earning less than $30,000 annually go online, and just 25% have broadband at home [9]. 
![Adoption rates by income show a clear disparity between higher and lower-income seniors](image3)

**Education Levels**: 
- Seniors with a college degree have much higher adoption rates, with 87% going online and 76% having broadband at home [7], [9]. Conversely, only 40% of seniors who have not attended college go online, and just 27% have broadband at home [9]. 
![Higher education correlates with significantly higher internet and broadband adoption](image3)

**Cell Phone and Smartphone Adoption**: 
- Cell phone ownership is high across income and education groups, with 92% of seniors earning $75,000+ owning a cell phone, compared to 67% of those earning less than $30,000 [5], [image5]. Smartphone adoption, however, remains low among seniors, with only 18% overall adoption. Yet, 42% of seniors earning $75,000+ own smartphones, while just 8% of those earning less than $30,000 do [10], [image5].
![Smartphone adoption rates are notably lower among seniors, especially in lower-income brackets](image5)

In summary, internet, broadband, cell phone, and smartphone adoption rates among seniors are strongly influenced by income and education, with higher-income and more educated seniors adopting these technologies at much higher rates.

Internet and smartphone adoption rates among older adults (65+) show significant variation based on income and education, reflecting broader patterns of technology access. Affluent and well-educated seniors are far more likely to adopt these technologies compared to those with lower income and educational attainment. For example, 90% of seniors with a household income of $75,000+ go online, compared to just 39% of those earning less than $30,000 [5]. Similarly, 87% of college graduates in this age group are internet users, versus 40% of those with a high school education or less [5]. ![Breakdown of internet usage by income and education among seniors](image5)

Broadband adoption follows a similar pattern, with 82% of seniors in the highest income bracket having broadband at home, compared to only 25% of those in the lowest income group [5]. College graduates are also more than twice as likely to have broadband as those with less education [5].

Smartphone ownership is much lower among older adults overall, with only 18% of seniors owning a smartphone [10]. However, this rate increases significantly with income and education. For instance, 42% of seniors with a household income of $75,000+ own a smartphone, while only 8% of those earning less than $30,000 do [4]. Similarly, 35% of college graduates own smartphones, compared to just 10% of those with a high school education or less [4]. ![Breakdown of smartphone ownership by income and education among seniors](image4)

These disparities align with broader trends in device ownership. Nationally, higher income and education levels correlate with greater adoption of technology. Seniors trail the general population in smartphone ownership, with a 55% national adoption rate compared to only 18% among seniors [10]. However, the gap narrows for basic cell phone ownership, with 77% of seniors owning a cell phone, close to the national average of 91% [4]. ![Comparison of smartphone ownership rates between seniors and the general population](image2)

In summary, income and education strongly influence internet and smartphone adoption among older adults, mirroring broader societal trends. Higher income and education levels significantly increase access to these technologies.

Seniors with higher educational backgrounds tend to have significantly higher rates of internet usage and smartphone ownership compared to those with lower levels of education. According to the data, **87% of college graduate seniors go online**, while only **40% of those with a high school education or less do the same**. Similarly, **35% of college-educated seniors own smartphones**, whereas just **10% of those with a high school education or less are smartphone adopters** [2][5][10].

![College graduate seniors have the highest internet and smartphone adoption rates among senior education groups](image2)

![Smartphone ownership is significantly higher among college-educated seniors compared to those with a high school education](image5)

This disparity reflects a broader trend where education plays a key role in technology adoption among older adults. Seniors with some college education also show higher adoption rates than those with only a high school diploma, but they still trail behind college graduates [2][5][10]. Overall, education is a strong predictor of internet and smartphone usage among seniors.

Internet and broadband adoption, as well as cell phone and smartphone ownership, vary significantly among seniors based on their education and income levels. 

For education, seniors with a college degree show higher engagement with technology. Fully **87%** of college-educated seniors go online, and **76%** have broadband at home, compared to just **40%** and **27%** respectively for those without a college degree [1]. Similarly, college graduates are more likely to own cell phones (**87%**) and smartphones (**35%**) than those with a high school diploma or less (**70%** and **10%**) [image2].

Income also plays a crucial role. Seniors with an annual household income of **$75,000 or more** are far more likely to go online (**90%**) and have broadband (**82%**) compared to those earning less than **$30,000** (**39%** and **25%**) [3]. This trend extends to device ownership, where higher-income seniors are more likely to own cell phones (**92%**) and smartphones (**42%**) than their lower-income counterparts (**67%** and **8%**) [image2].

![Seniors with higher education and income levels show greater internet and broadband adoption.](image3)  
![Cell phone and smartphone ownership increases with higher education and income levels.](image2)  

In summary, both education and income significantly influence seniors’ adoption of internet, broadband, and mobile technologies, with higher levels in both categories correlating with greater usage and ownership.

Broadband adoption at home among seniors varies significantly based on their educational attainment and household income. Seniors with a college degree are much more likely to have broadband at home compared to those without a college education. Specifically, 76% of college-educated seniors are broadband adopters, while only 27% of seniors who have not attended college have broadband at home [2][10]. 

Similarly, household income plays a crucial role. Among seniors with an annual income of $75,000 or more, 82% have broadband at home, whereas only 25% of seniors earning less than $30,000 annually are broadband adopters [10]. ![Broadband adoption rates by household income and education](image2) These disparities highlight the impact of socioeconomic factors on technology access for older adults. Broadband adoption is significantly higher among seniors with higher education and income levels compared to those with lower socioeconomic status.

Seniors with higher education levels are significantly more likely to adopt tablets and e-book readers compared to those with less education. College graduates are around three times more likely to own these devices than seniors who have not attended college. Additionally, seniors with an annual household income of $75,000 or more are about four times as likely to own each device compared to those with incomes below $30,000 [4]. 

![Seniors with higher education and income levels show greater adoption of e-book readers and tablets](image3)

When comparing adoption trends over time, older adults have steadily increased their use of technology, but this adoption is still influenced by factors like age and education. For instance, only 18% of all seniors own a tablet or e-book reader, which is lower than the national average of 34% for tablets and 24% for e-book readers [3][6]. However, the adoption rate is higher among younger seniors (ages 65-69) and those with college degrees or higher incomes [4].

![Technology adoption among seniors has increased, but remains lower than national averages](image2)

In contrast, technology adoption among younger age groups is more widespread and less dependent on education or income. For example, 86% of all adults aged 18+ use cell phones, while only 77% of seniors do. Similarly, smartphone ownership drops significantly among older age groups, with only 18% of seniors owning one compared to 59% of all adults [image5]. This highlights the disparity in technology adoption between younger adults and seniors, with education and income playing a more pronounced role in the latter group. 

Overall, education level significantly impacts the adoption of tablets and e-book readers among seniors, with higher adoption rates among college graduates and higher-income individuals, while technology adoption among seniors remains lower than younger age groups.

Educational attainment significantly influences how workers perceive the impact of workforce technologies. Workers with higher levels of formal education, such as college graduates, are more likely to view technology positively, with 64% stating it has made their work more interesting and 53% reporting increased opportunities for career advancement [6][10]. In contrast, workers with high school diplomas or less are less optimistic, with only 38% finding their work more interesting and 32% seeing improved career prospects due to technology [7][10]. ![College graduates are more likely to find work interesting and see career advancement opportunities due to technology](image1)

When it comes to driverless car technology, many Americans anticipate significant developments in the coming decades. Fully 94% of the public is aware of driverless vehicle efforts, and approximately two-thirds expect most vehicles on the road to be driverless within the next half-century, with 9% predicting this will happen in the next 10 years [2]. ![Public expectations for the adoption of driverless car technology vary across timeframes](image2)

In summary, educational attainment shapes workers' perceptions of technology, with higher education correlating with more positive views, while driverless car technology is widely expected to advance significantly in the coming decades.

Workers with higher levels of education tend to have more positive views of workplace technologies compared to those with lower educational attainment. For instance, 90% of college graduates feel that office productivity tools like word processing or spreadsheet software have had a positive impact on their careers, while only 45% of workers with high school diplomas or less share this view [4]. Similar disparities exist for other technologies, such as smartphones (76% vs. 54%), email or social media (72% vs. 45%), and software managing daily schedules (54% vs. 42%) [4]. Additionally, 24% of workers with high school diplomas or less say none of the six measured technologies has positively impacted their jobs, compared to just 2% of college graduates [4].

![Workers with higher education view workplace technologies more favorably than those with lower education.](image5)

When it comes to the broader impact of technology, workers with higher education also report increased opportunities for career advancement and find their work more interesting due to technology [10]. Conversely, workers with lower education levels are more likely to feel negatively impacted, with one-in-ten stating that technology has harmed their careers [3]. 

![Technology has made work more interesting for many, but less interesting for some.](image6)

As for the adoption of driverless cars, 94% of Americans are aware of their development, and two-thirds predict that most vehicles on the road will be driverless within the next 50 years. Notably, 9% believe this will happen within the next decade [1].

![Many Americans expect driverless cars to dominate roads within the next 50 years.](image1)

In summary, workers with higher education perceive workplace technologies more positively, while expectations for driverless car adoption are high, with significant awareness and anticipation of their widespread use in the coming decades.

The perceptions of automation and workforce technology impacts vary significantly between future expectations for driverless vehicles and the current experiences of U.S. workers with existing technologies.  

Currently, workers express a mix of positive, negative, and neutral views on the impact of technologies like word processing, smartphones, email, and industrial robots. For instance, *70%* feel that word processing or spreadsheet software has positively impacted their careers, and *67%* report the same for smartphones. However, industrial robots are viewed more skeptically, with only *27%* seeing a positive impact, while *58%* feel they have had no impact either way [3][4]. ![A visualization of workers' perceptions of various technologies](image1)  

In contrast, future expectations for driverless vehicles reflect widespread anticipation of change, though with mixed emotions. *94%* of Americans are aware of driverless vehicle efforts, and *two-thirds* expect most vehicles to be driverless within the next 50 years, with *9%* predicting this shift within a decade. While some see potential benefits, many express concern about the broader societal implications of such automation [5][6]. ![A timeline projection of when driverless vehicles are expected to dominate](image2)  

For current workforce technologies, workers' experiences are influenced by their educational attainment. Those with higher education levels are more likely to view technology as a positive force, enhancing career opportunities and making work more interesting. In contrast, workers without college education are less optimistic, often perceiving these technologies as neutral or negative [8]. ![Workers' views on whether technology has made their work more or less interesting](image5) ![Workers' perceptions of how technology has impacted their career opportunities](image4)  

Overall, while current experiences with workforce technologies are mixed, with both positive and negative sentiments, future expectations for driverless vehicles are marked by a broader awareness and anticipation of transformative change, often accompanied by societal concerns.

Workers’ perceptions of workplace technologies vary significantly based on their education level, particularly in how they view the impact on job interest and career opportunities. College graduates are substantially more likely to report positive effects compared to those with high school diplomas or less. For instance, 64% of college graduates say technology has made their work more interesting, compared to only 38% of those with high school diplomas or less [2]. Similarly, 53% of college graduates feel technology has increased their career advancement opportunities, while only 32% of those with less education share this sentiment [2]. ![College graduates are more likely to view technology as enhancing job interest and career opportunities](image3)

Workers with some college education but no degree fall between these two groups, expressing more positive views than those with less education but less positive than college graduates [4]. For example, 54% of workers with some college education report that technology has made their work more interesting, compared to 38% of those with high school diplomas or less [3]. ![Workers with some college education exhibit intermediate levels of positive views on technology](image3)

When examining specific technologies, these educational disparities persist. College graduates are more likely to view office productivity tools like word processing and spreadsheet software positively, with a 45-percentage point gap between college graduates (90%) and those with high school diplomas or less (45%) [9]. Similar gaps exist for email or social media, smartphones, and scheduling software [9]. ![Educational differences in perceptions of specific workplace technologies](image4)

Overall, workers with higher education levels are more likely to view workplace technologies as beneficial, particularly in making work more interesting and enhancing career opportunities, while those with less education are more likely to report neutral or negative impacts [2][10]. ![Workers generally express positive views on technology, but education level influences perceptions](image2) ![Education level affects perceptions of technology's impact on career opportunities](image1) ![Mixed views on whether technology makes work more or less demanding](image5)

Workers with higher levels of educational attainment, particularly those with college degrees, are significantly more likely to view technology as having a positive impact on their work compared to those with high school diplomas or less. For example, 64% of college graduates say technology has made their work more interesting, compared to only 38% of workers with high school diplomas or less [1][5]. Similarly, 53% of college graduates feel technology has increased their opportunities for career advancement, while only 32% of those with lower educational attainment share this view [1][2]. ![College graduates are more likely to find work more interesting and see increased opportunities due to technology](image5)

These differences extend to specific technologies as well. College graduates are much more likely to report positive impacts from tools like word processing or spreadsheet software (90% vs. 45% for those with high school diplomas or less), smartphones (76% vs. 54%), and email or social media (72% vs. 45%) [8][9]. ![Workers with higher education report more positive impacts from specific technologies](image3)

In contrast, nearly one-quarter (24%) of workers with high school diplomas or less say that none of the six measured technologies has had a positive impact on their jobs or careers, compared to just 2% of college graduates [5][9]. ![Workers with higher education are more likely to view technology as beneficial](image2)

Overall, educational attainment plays a critical role in shaping workers’ perceptions of technology’s impact, with higher education correlating with more positive views on both the enrichment of work and career advancement opportunities. ![Education level significantly influences perceptions of technology’s impact](image4)

Workers with higher levels of education, such as college graduates, tend to have more positive perceptions of technology's impact on their job opportunities and work interest compared to those with lower educational attainment. For instance, 64% of college graduates say technology has made their work more interesting, while only 38% of workers with high school diplomas or less share this view [9]. Similarly, 53% of college graduates believe technology has increased their opportunities for career advancement, compared to just 32% of those with high school diplomas or less [9].

![College graduates are more likely to view technology as enhancing work interest and opportunities compared to those with lower education levels](image3)

These differences are also evident when examining specific technologies. For example, 90% of college graduates feel that office productivity tools like word processing or spreadsheet software have had a positive impact on their professional lives, while only 45% of workers with high school diplomas or less agree [10]. This 45-percentage point gap is the largest among the technologies surveyed, but significant differences exist for other tools as well, such as email or social media (a 27-point gap), smartphones (a 22-point gap), and scheduling software (a 21-point gap) [10].

![Educational differences in perceptions of specific workplace technologies](image1)

In contrast, a substantial portion of workers with lower educational attainment report that technology has not significantly impacted their careers, whether positively or negatively. For example, 44% of workers with high school diplomas or less say that word processing or spreadsheet software has had no meaningful impact on their professional lives [7]. This contrasts sharply with the views of college-educated workers, who are far more likely to see technology as a positive force in their careers.

In summary, workers with higher education levels are more likely to perceive technology as enhancing their job opportunities and making their work more interesting, while those with lower educational attainment often feel neutral or negative about its impact.

Americans' levels of awareness about automation significantly influence their enthusiasm and worry regarding machines taking over human jobs. Those who have heard a lot about this concept are more likely to find it realistic and express higher levels of enthusiasm, with 47% of highly aware individuals feeling somewhat or very enthusiastic. However, they also express substantial concerns, with 76% of this group worrying about such a future. This is comparable to those who have heard little (72%) or nothing at all (69%) about the concept, showing that worry remains consistently high across all levels of awareness [3][6][7][9].

![Americans' enthusiasm and worry about automation vary with awareness levels](image3)

When it comes to expected outcomes, most Americans foresee more negative than positive consequences. Around 76% expect increased economic inequality, and only 25% believe the economy will create many new, well-paying jobs for humans. Other anticipated negative outcomes include people struggling to find meaningful activities and jobs becoming less appealing. On the positive side, some expect automation to make the economy more efficient, allow people to focus on fulfilling aspects of their jobs, or spend less time working and more on what matters to them [1][8][10]. 

![Americans' views on possible outcomes of widespread automation](image4)

In summary, while awareness increases enthusiasm for automation, it does not reduce worry. Americans predominantly expect negative outcomes, such as greater inequality and fewer job opportunities, alongside some potential efficiencies and personal benefits.

Public opinion on workforce automation policies varies significantly between Democrats and Republicans, particularly on issues like universal basic income and national service programs. Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents are much more supportive of these policies, with 77% favoring a universal basic income compared to just 38% of Republicans. Similarly, 66% of Democrats support a national service program for displaced workers, while only 46% of Republicans do [2][9]. However, there is broad bipartisan agreement on limiting machines to dangerous and unhealthy jobs, with 86% of Democrats and 86% of Republicans in favor [3][6]. ![Majority of Democrats and Republicans support limiting machines to dangerous jobs](image3)  

Overall, the public is highly supportive of policies that restrict machines to dangerous or dirty jobs, with 85% of Americans favoring this idea [6]. Yet, there is less consensus on other policies, such as guaranteed income or national service programs, which see more partisan divisions [9]. ![Public strongly favors limiting machines to dangerous jobs](image5)

Political affiliations and education levels significantly shape opinions on government obligations and automation limits related to job displacement. Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents are more likely to support government intervention, with 65% believing the government has an obligation to care for displaced workers, even if it means higher taxes, compared to only 30% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents who hold this view. ![Partisan differences in government obligations](image4)

Educational attainment also plays a role in shaping opinions, though in a different pattern. Those with lower levels of education, such as high school diplomas or less, are more supportive of limiting the number of jobs businesses can automate, with 70% favoring such limits. In contrast, only 41% of those with four-year college degrees support this idea. ![Education differences in automation limits](image4)

On the question of whether businesses should be limited in replacing human jobs with machines, partisan differences are less pronounced, with 54% of Republicans and 60% of Democrats supporting such limits. ![Partisan alignment on automation limits](image4)

In summary, Democrats and those with lower educational attainment are more supportive of government intervention and limits on automation, while Republicans and those with higher education lean toward individual responsibility and fewer restrictions on businesses. ![Summary of political and educational influences](image4)

Political affiliations significantly shape Americans’ views on policies related to workforce automation and job displacement. Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents are *much more supportive* of policies like a universal basic income ($77\%$ vs. $38\%$ of Republicans) and a national service program for displaced workers ($66\%$ vs. $46\%$ of Republicans) [1][2][10]. ![Democrats and Republicans vary strongly in support for a universal basic income and national service program](image4)

On the other hand, there is broad bipartisan agreement on limiting machines to dangerous and dirty jobs, with both Democrats and Republicans overwhelmingly supporting this idea [1][10]. ![Most Americans agree on limiting machines to dangerous or unhealthy jobs](image4)

When it comes to the government's role in assisting displaced workers, $65\%$ of Democrats believe the government has an obligation to help, even if it means higher taxes, while $68\%$ of Republicans think individuals should be responsible for their own financial well-being [4][3]. ![Partisan divisions on the government’s obligation to help displaced workers](image3)

There is also notable alignment on limiting the number of jobs businesses can replace with machines, with $60\%$ of Democrats and $54\%$ of Republicans favoring such limits [6][10]. ![Partisan alignment on limits to job automation by businesses](image3) Overall, political affiliation strongly influences support for government-led solutions like guaranteed income and national service, but there is bipartisan consensus on certain aspects, such as restricting machines to hazardous tasks and limiting job automation by businesses.

Attitudes towards workforce automation and the perceived impact of technology vary significantly across different age groups and education levels. Younger adults, particularly those aged 18 to 24, are among the most likely to have been personally impacted by workforce automation, with some experiencing job losses or reduced pay due to technological advancements [2]. ![Younger adults are more likely to face automation impacts](image3).

Workers with higher levels of education tend to view workplace technologies more positively. College graduates are more likely to report that technology has made their work more interesting and increased their opportunities for career advancement compared to those with only a high school diploma or less [8]. ![College graduates see more positive impacts from technology](image4). For example, 64% of college graduates say technology has made their work more interesting, compared to just 38% of those with a high school diploma or less [8]. Similarly, 53% of college graduates feel technology has increased their career advancement opportunities, versus 32% of less-educated workers [8].

Conversely, workers without a college education are more likely to express negative attitudes towards workforce technologies. Many feel that technology has decreased their career opportunities or made their work less interesting [5]. ![Workers without college education see fewer benefits from technology](image4). Additionally, workers who have already been impacted by automation, often those with lower educational attainment, express strongly negative views about the future impact of technology on their careers. Nearly six-in-ten (57%) of these workers anticipate their jobs will mostly be done by machines within their lifetimes, compared to 28% of workers who have not been impacted by automation [6].

These disparities highlight how educational attainment and age shape workers' perceptions of technology’s role in their careers, with more educated individuals generally viewing it as a positive force, while less educated and younger workers often see it as a threat.

Workers’ perceptions of the impact of workforce automation and technology vary significantly based on their educational attainment. College graduates are substantially more likely to view technology positively compared to those with high school diplomas or less. For instance, 64% of college graduates say technology has made their work more interesting, while only 38% of less-educated workers share this view. Similarly, 53% of college graduates believe technology has increased their opportunities for career advancement, versus 32% of their less-educated counterparts [1]![College graduates are more likely to view technology positively](image4).

The survey highlights that workers with higher education levels are more likely to see technology as enhancing their jobs, while those without college education often view it as damaging or neutral to their career prospects [2][4]. Specifically, 27% of workers feel positively about industrial robots, and 25% about customer self-serve technologies, but these positive sentiments are more common among educated workers [10]![Workers express mixed opinions on technology’s impact](image5).

Additionally, workforce automation has already impacted some workers negatively, particularly those without college degrees, leading to job losses or reduced wages. This group is more likely to see technology as a negative force in their careers [4]. Overall, the benefits of workforce technologies are disproportionately experienced by workers with higher levels of formal education [6].![Workforce technologies have disparate impacts](image4)

Workers' perceptions of their job's interest and advancement opportunities are significantly influenced by their education levels and the specific technologies they use. Workers with higher levels of education, such as college graduates, are more likely to view technology positively in these areas. For example, 64% of college graduates report that technology has made their work more interesting, compared to only 38% of those with a high school diploma or less. Similarly, 54% of college graduates say technology has increased their opportunities for career advancement, while only 32% of those with less education share this view [1][3][7].

![Workers with higher education are more likely to report technology increases job interest and advancement opportunities](image1)

When it comes to specific technologies, tools like word processing or spreadsheet software, smartphones, and email or social media are seen as having the most positive impact. For instance, 70% of workers say word processing or spreadsheet software has positively impacted their careers, 67% say the same about smartphones, and 60% about email or social media [9]. However, the benefits of these technologies are not evenly distributed. College-educated workers are substantially more likely than non-college-educated workers to say each of these technologies has positively impacted their jobs or careers [5].

![Workers express varied opinions on the impact of specific technologies on their careers](image5)

Overall, while many workers view technology as a positive force that enhances their work experience and career prospects, those with lower levels of education are less likely to share this optimistic perspective. This disparity highlights the uneven impact of technology across different segments of the workforce [3][8].

Younger adults, particularly those aged 18 to 29, are more likely to experience amusement from social media content, with 54% saying they frequently feel this way, compared to 30% of users aged 65 and older [1]. However, older adults encounter content that makes them feel amused and angry at more comparable rates (30% vs. 24%, respectively) [1]. Younger adults are also more likely to feel lonely due to social media content, with 15% reporting this, compared to just 4% of those aged 50 and older [5].

![Different emotions experienced by various age groups on social media](image2)

Across all users, amusement is the most frequently experienced emotion, with 88% of users saying they see content that makes them feel amused and 44% reporting they frequently experience this emotion [7]. Anger is also a common emotion, with 27% of younger adults and 24% of older adults frequently feeling this way [1]. 

![Most frequently experienced emotions across all social media users](image3)

In summary, while amusement is the most common emotion across all age groups, younger users experience it more frequently. Older users, however, encounter both amused and angry feelings at more comparable rates, and younger adults are more prone to feelings of loneliness.

Different age groups experience a range of emotions on social media, with some notable variations by age. Younger adults (ages 18-29) are more likely to feel both amused and lonely compared to older adults. For instance, 54% of 18-29-year-olds frequently encounter content that amuses them, while 15% report feeling lonely often [1][7]. In contrast, only 30% of those 65 and older feel amused frequently, and just 4% of those 50 and older feel lonely [1]. Anger, however, is a common emotion across all age groups, with similar percentages reporting they frequently encounter content that makes them feel angry [1][7]. ![Story of emotions across age groups](image1)

Regarding the types of content frequently encountered, users across all age groups are most often exposed to overly dramatic or exaggerated posts (58%) and people making accusations or starting arguments without all the facts (59%) [5]. Additionally, younger adults are more likely to see content that makes them feel connected or inspired compared to older adults, though the differences are less pronounced [1]. ![Frequently encountered social media content](image4)

These findings highlight the varied emotional experiences and content exposure across different age groups on social media.

Younger social media users, particularly those aged 18-29, are more likely to feel amused, lonely, and depressed by content they encounter, while older adults, especially those 65 and older, report feeling both amused and angry at similar rates [7]. ![Graph showing emotional responses across age groups](image2) In terms of gender, men are slightly more likely than women to encounter mean or bullying behavior online, with 29% of men reporting this compared to 19% of women. Conversely, women are slightly more likely to see kind or supportive behavior [2]. ![Graph comparing behaviors seen by gender](image4)

Across all age groups, the most common types of content encountered are overly dramatic or exaggerated posts (58%) and people making accusations or starting arguments without all the facts (59%) [4]. ![Graph showing types of content frequently encountered](image5) Additionally, a majority of users (54%) see an equal mix of kind and bullying behavior, while 21% more often see kindness and 24% more often see meanness [9].

In summary, younger users experience a wider range of emotions on social media, while older users report similar levels of amusement and anger. Men encounter more negative behavior, and women see more kindness, with dramatic and argumentative content being the most prevalent across all demographics.

Different age groups and genders experience emotions and behaviors on social media in varied ways, and they also encounter distinct types of content frequently. 

![Age groups experience varying emotions on social media, with younger users feeling more amused and older users more angry.](image4)  
Younger users (18-29) are most likely to feel *amused* (54%) and *connected* (25%) on social media, while older users (65+) are more likely to feel *angry* (27%) and less *inspired* (9%). Age seems to influence emotional responses, with younger users generally experiencing more positive emotions compared to older users.

![Men and women see different behaviors on social media, with men more likely to encounter bullying and women more likely to see kindness.](image3)  
Gender also plays a role in how behaviors are perceived. Men (29%) are slightly more likely than women (19%) to encounter *mean or bullying behavior* on social media, while women are more likely to see *kind or supportive behavior*. However, the majority of both genders (52% of men and 56% of women) report seeing an *equal mix* of supportive and bullying behavior.

![Users frequently encounter posts that are overly dramatic or exaggerated, as well as posts where people make accusations without all the facts.](image5)  
The most common types of posts users encounter are *overly dramatic or exaggerated posts* (58% frequently see this) and posts where people *make accusations or start arguments without having all the facts* (59% frequently see this). These types of content are prevalent across age groups and genders.

In summary, younger users tend to feel more positive emotions like amusement and connection, while older users are more likely to feel anger. Men are slightly more likely to encounter bullying, whereas women see more kindness. Across all demographics, users frequently encounter dramatic posts and arguments based on incomplete information.

Men and women perceive online behaviors like bullying, deception, and correcting misinformation differently, and these perceptions are influenced by the frequency of dramatic or exaggerated posts they encounter on social media.  

Men are somewhat more likely than women to report seeing people being deceptive or bullying on social media. Specifically, 24% of men say they more often see people being deceptive, compared to 13% of women [5][9]. Similarly, 29% of men report more often encountering mean or bullying behavior, versus 19% of women [10]. On the other hand, women are slightly more likely than men to say they see people being kind or supportive (21% vs. an unspecified lower percentage) [8].  

When it comes to correcting misinformation, both genders predominantly report seeing an equal mix of deceptive behavior and attempts to correct inaccuracies (58% of men and 67% of women) [5]. However, men are twice as likely as women to say they more often see people being deceptive (24% vs. 13%), while 17% of users overall say they more often see people trying to point out inaccurate information, with no significant gender gap here [5].  

These differences in perception may be related to the frequent exposure to dramatic or exaggerated posts on social media. ![People frequently see dramatic or exaggerated posts on social media](image4) A majority of users (58%) frequently encounter posts that are overly dramatic or exaggerated, and 59% frequently see people making accusations or starting arguments without having all the facts [3][7]. This environment of heightened drama and conflict could contribute to the divergence in how men and women perceive online behaviors.  

In summary, men are more likely to report seeing deceptive or bullying behavior, while women are slightly more likely to notice kindness. Both genders largely encounter an equal mix of correcting misinformation and deception, but men are more sensitive to negative behaviors, possibly influenced by the prevalence of dramatic or exaggerated content on social media.

Men and women exhibit distinct perceptions of social media content and behavior, which can inform how platforms tailor recommendations and advertisements. For instance, men are slightly more likely than women to encounter harassing or abusive behavior online, with 29% of men and 19% of women reporting that they more often see people being mean or bullying content [4]. Conversely, women are slightly more likely than men to say they more often see people being kind or supportive [4]. However, the majority of both genders (52% of men and 56% of women) report seeing an equal mix of supportive and bullying behavior [4].  

![People being kind or supportive vs. mean or bullying on social media](image2)

Similarly, men are around twice as likely as women to say they more often see people being deceptive on social media (24% vs. 13%) [10]. Yet, majorities of both men (58%) and women (67%) see an equal mix of deceptiveness and attempts to correct misinformation [10].  

These differences in perceptions suggest that social media platforms should consider gender-specific approaches when tailoring content. For example, platforms could prioritize fostering supportive interactions for women, while addressing bullying and deceptive behavior more prominently for men. Additionally, advertising strategies could be adjusted to align with these preferences, such as emphasizing positive and informative content for women and addressing concerns about misinformation for men. 

![People being deceptive vs. trying to correct misinformation on social media](image2)

In summary, understanding these gender-based differences in content perception allows social media platforms to create more personalized and effective user experiences.

Social media users’ comfort with their data being used varies significantly by age and context. A majority of users across all age groups, from 18 to 65+, find it acceptable for platforms to use their data to recommend events in their area, with approval rates ranging from 67% to 80% [1][9]. However, younger users (18–49) are more accepting of their data being used to recommend people they might know, with 66% finding it acceptable, compared to only 36% of users aged 65 and older [6][10]. 

When it comes to advertising, acceptability is more divided. About 60% of users aged 18–49 find it acceptable for their data to be used for product or service ads, while only 39% of those aged 65+ agree [image1][10]. Political campaign messaging sees the lowest approval, with only 31% of users aged 65+ and 40% of those aged 18–29 finding it acceptable [image1][5]. 

These differences highlight that younger users are generally more comfortable with broader uses of their data, while older users are more skeptical, particularly regarding personal connections and political messaging. Overall, users’ comfort is highly context-dependent, with event recommendations being the most widely accepted use, while political messaging is the least favored [8][9]. ![Approval rates for data usage across age groups](image1) ![Overall acceptability levels for different data uses](image2)

Perceptions of fairness and effectiveness vary significantly across different automated decision-making systems, reflecting contextual nuances and public skepticism. While 54% of Americans believe that an *automated personal finance score* would be effective at identifying good customers, only 32% consider it fair to consumers—a 22-percentage-point difference, the largest among the scenarios analyzed [1][3][8]. Similarly, the *automated video job interview analysis* is seen as effective by 39% but fair by only 33%, indicating a skepticism about its fairness to job applicants [3][7]. In contrast, the *automated criminal risk score* is viewed as fair by 50% and effective by 49%, suggesting a more balanced perception [1][3][7].

![Automated systems' effectiveness and fairness ratings](image3)

Demographic differences also play a role. Black and Hispanic respondents are more likely than whites to view the *personal finance score* as fair (45% and 47% vs. 25%), while Black respondents express greater concern about the fairness of the *criminal risk score* (61% think it’s unfair) compared to whites (49%) and Hispanics (38%) [3]. This racial variation highlights how perceptions are shaped by lived experiences and societal contexts.

![Reasons for acceptability of automated personal finance scores](image2)

Broadly, the public is skeptical about the fairness of these systems, with 58% believing that algorithms will always reflect human bias [6]. This skepticism is reinforced by concerns about privacy violations, lack of nuance, and potential discrimination [6][10]. For instance, 68% find the *personal finance score* algorithm unacceptable, primarily citing privacy violations (26%) and unfairness (26%) [9]. These perceptions suggest a lack of trust in automated systems, particularly when they are perceived as invasive or discriminatory.

![Public belief in algorithmic bias](image1)

In summary, while some systems like the *criminal risk score* are seen as relatively fair and effective, others like the *personal finance score* and *video job interview analysis* face significant skepticism. These differences reflect deeper concerns about bias, privacy, and fairness, indicating that public trust in automated decision-making systems is highly contextual and often lacking.

Perceptions of Trump's ethical standards and trustworthiness compared to previous presidents vary significantly across political affiliations. 

For Republicans and Republican leaners, **58%** trust what Trump says more than previous presidents, while **25%** trust him about the same, and only **15%** trust him less [6]. Additionally, **76%** of Republicans and Republican leaners rate the ethical standards of top Trump administration officials as excellent or good, with **16%** describing them as “excellent” [10]. ![Majority of Republicans trust Trump more than previous presidents](image4)

In contrast, **94%** of Democrats and Democratic leaners trust what Trump says less than previous presidents [2], and **90%** rate the ethical standards of top Trump administration officials as not good or poor, with **67%** describing them as “poor” [10]. ![Most Democrats distrust Trump compared to previous presidents](image4)

Overall, public trust in Trump’s statements is lower than for previous presidents, with **58%** of the total population trusting him less, **26%** trusting him more, and **14%** trusting him about the same [9]. ![Public trust in Trump is lower than for previous presidents](image1)

Ethical evaluations of Trump administration officials are also significantly lower than those of officials in the previous five administrations, often measured during specific ethical controversies [7]. ![Ethical standards of Trump officials are lower than previous administrations](image3)

In summary, Republicans predominantly view Trump’s ethical standards and trustworthiness more favorably than previous presidents, while Democrats overwhelmingly distrust him and rate his administration’s ethics poorly.

Public perceptions of Trump’s responsibilities and trustworthiness differ significantly from those of previous presidents, with strong partisan divides shaping these views. A majority of the public (58%) says they trust what Trump says less than they trusted previous presidents, while only 26% trust him more [10]. This distrust is particularly pronounced among Democrats and Democratic leaners, with 94% stating they trust Trump less than previous presidents [5]. In contrast, most Republicans and Republican leaners (58%) trust Trump more than previous presidents, with 25% trusting him about the same and only 15% trusting him less [8]. ![Most Democrats trust Trump less than previous presidents](image3)

On the issue of responsibilities, 64% of the public believes Trump has a responsibility to release his tax returns, including 91% of Democrats and 32% of Republicans [3]. This contrasts with previous administrations, where such demands were less pronounced. Ethical standards of Trump administration officials are also viewed more negatively compared to previous administrations, often reaching record lows [2][4]. ![Trump’s ethical standards are viewed lower than previous administrations](image5)

Additionally, early assessments of Trump’s success differ from those of previous presidents. A smaller share of the public (38%) says it’s too early to tell if Trump will be successful, compared to 47% for Obama, 38% for George W. Bush, and 43% for Clinton at similar points in their presidencies [6]. ![Public views on Trump’s success differ from previous presidents](image2)

Economic perceptions, however, are more favorable, with 40% believing Trump’s policies have improved economic conditions, compared to 28% who say they’ve made conditions worse [1]. ![Public views on Trump’s economic impact](image4) Overall, public perceptions of Trump’s trustworthiness and responsibilities are more critical than for previous presidents, with stark partisan divides influencing these views.

Public perceptions of Trump’s presidency reveal significant partisan divides in trust, ethical standards, economic impact, and long-term success. Republicans and Democrats hold starkly contrasting views, and these perceptions often differ from those of previous presidents.

**Trust and Ethical Standards**: Ethical standards of Trump administration officials are viewed more negatively than those of previous administrations, with 90% of Democrats saying they are “not good” or “poor,” compared to 76% of Republicans who say they are “excellent” or “good” [10]. ![Ethical standards are perceived more negatively than in previous administrations](image1). This polarization surpasses historical norms, as partisan gaps in ethical perceptions were less pronounced for earlier presidents like Bush and Obama.

**Economic Impact**: Views on Trump’s economic policies are highly polarized. Nearly 79% of Republicans believe his policies have improved economic conditions, up from 63% in October 2017, while 46% of Democrats say they have made conditions worse [9]. ![Economic perceptions are deeply divided along partisan lines](image4). This contrasts with previous administrations, where economic views were less polarized. For example, Bush and Obama did not face such a stark partisan divide in their economic evaluations [8].

**Long-Term Success**: Republicans are optimistic about Trump’s long-term success, with 65% believing he will be successful, while 88% of Democrats predict he will be unsuccessful [3]. ![Partisan views on Trump’s long-term success are highly polarized](image3). This divide is more pronounced than for previous presidents. For instance, at comparable points in their presidencies, Bush and Obama had higher shares of the public saying it was “too early to tell” about their long-term success [2].

Compared to his predecessors, Trump’s presidency is marked by deeper partisan divisions and lower overall public confidence, particularly in ethical standards and long-term success. ![Public perceptions of Trump’s legacy are more negative than for previous presidents](image5). 

In summary, perceptions of Trump’s presidency are deeply polarized, with Republicans generally supportive and Democrats critical, and these contrasts are more pronounced than for previous presidents.

Perceptions of Trump’s presidency among party affiliates are significantly more polarized compared to those of Obama, Bush, and Clinton. Among Republicans and Republican-leaning independents, 65% believe Trump will be a successful president in the long run, while 80% of Democrats and Democratic leaners think he will be unsuccessful [1][5]. This stark partisan divide is more pronounced than for previous presidents. For example, at comparable points in their presidencies, fewer Democrats held such negative views of Obama or Bush, and fewer Republicans had such uniformly positive views [6].

![Republicans and Democrats have starkly different views on Trump’s success compared to past presidents.](image1)

The share of those who say it is “too early to tell” about Trump’s success is much lower than for Obama (47%), Bush (38%), or Clinton (43%) at similar stages [4]. This suggests that public opinion on Trump has solidified earlier, with fewer people undecided about his legacy [6].

![Public opinion on Trump’s success has solidified earlier compared to Obama, Bush, and Clinton.](image3)

Partisan views of Trump’s economic policies have also become more polarized. In January 2019, 79% of Republicans and Republican leaners said his policies improved economic conditions, up from 63% in October 2017. Meanwhile, 46% of Democrats said his policies made conditions worse, up from 28% in October 2017 [8]. This polarization contrasts with broader, less partisan views of past presidents’ economic impacts [7].

![Partisan views on Trump’s economic policies have become increasingly polarized over time.](image2)

In summary, perceptions of Trump’s presidency are more sharply divided along partisan lines than those of Obama, Bush, or Clinton, with fewer Americans undecided about his long-term success.

Republicans and Democratic respondents have starkly different perceptions of Trump’s potential success as president. About two-thirds of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents (65%) believe Trump will be successful in the long run, while an overwhelming 80% of Democrats and Democratic-leaners think he will be unsuccessful [3] [6]. Additionally, Republicans are slightly more likely than Democrats to say it is too early to tell about Trump’s success (25% vs. 16%) [1]. 

![Republicans are more likely to view Trump as successful, while Democrats overwhelmingly see him as unsuccessful](image3)

These perceptions of Trump’s success are closely tied to partisan views of the Mueller investigation. Democrats express high confidence in the fairness of Mueller’s investigation, with 72% being at least somewhat confident, while 58% of Republicans say they are not too or not at all confident in Mueller [7]. This partisan divide is further highlighted by the fact that 92% of Democrats lack confidence in Trump’s handling of matters related to the investigation, whereas 75% of Republicans are confident in his handling, including 42% who are very confident [9]. 

![Democrats have higher confidence in Mueller’s investigation, while Republicans express skepticism](image2)

Overall, these contrasting perceptions of Trump’s success and confidence in the Mueller investigation underscore the deep partisan divisions in public opinion. Republicans largely support Trump and doubt the investigation, while Democrats are critical of Trump and trust Mueller’s inquiry. 

![Public confidence in Mueller’s investigation remains steady but deeply divided along partisan lines](image5)

Perceptions of economic conditions and job availability show clear partisan divides, with Republicans generally holding more positive views than Democrats. Currently, 71% of Republicans believe there are plenty of jobs available locally, compared to 53% of Democrats [2]. This gap has persisted over time; in October 2017, 58% of Republicans and 47% of Democrats viewed jobs as widely available [2].

![Perceptions of job availability by political affiliation](image1)  
The chart illustrates the disparity between Republicans and Democrats in their views on job availability, with Republicans consistently reporting higher levels of optimism.

Trends over time reveal that perceptions of job availability have become more positive in recent years, reaching the highest levels recorded since the question was first asked in 2001 [3]. Six-in-ten adults now say there are plenty of jobs available in their local community, with just a third viewing jobs as difficult to find [3]. This positive shift has been observed in both parties, with views of local job opportunities now among the most favorable in the last two decades [5].

![Trends in job availability perceptions over time](image2)  
This graph shows the upward trend in positive perceptions of job availability, tracking the broader improvement in economic views since October 2017 [10].

However, while majorities in both parties agree that jobs are available, there is a divide in perceptions of “good jobs,” with fewer adults seeing them as widely accessible [4]. This gap between job availability and “good job” availability remains consistent with past trends [8].

![Perceptions of good job availability by political affiliation](image1)  
The chart highlights the partisan differences in views on “good job” availability, with Republicans again expressing more optimism than Democrats.

Republicans also rate their personal financial situations more positively, with 62% describing them as excellent or good, compared to 44% of Democrats [7]. This reflects the broader pattern of Republicans holding more favorable economic perceptions overall.

In summary, while both parties have seen improvements in their views of job availability over time, Republicans consistently report more positive perceptions than Democrats, both in terms of job availability and personal financial conditions.

Perceptions of job availability in the United States are sharply divided along partisan lines, with Republicans and Democrats holding significantly different views. Currently, 71% of Republicans and Republican leaners say there are plenty of jobs available locally, compared to 53% of Democrats and Democratic leaners [2][10]. This gap has widened since October 2017, when 58% of Republicans and 47% of Democrats held this view [10].

![Republicans and Democrats have differing views on job availability, with Republicans more positive](image2)

The public’s overall perception of job availability is the most positive it has been in decades, with 60% of Americans saying there are plenty of jobs in their communities—the highest percentage since Pew Research Center began tracking this in 2001 [7]. Both parties have seen an increase in positive views, with perceptions among Republicans and Democrats reaching their highest levels in the past two decades [3]. For Republicans, this optimism has been particularly strong since President Trump’s election, with 75% now rating economic conditions as excellent or good [9].

![Perceptions of job availability have risen significantly since 2001](image3)

Over time, the partisan gap in views of job availability has grown, reflecting broader polarization in economic perceptions. In 2001, the difference between Republicans and Democrats was relatively small, but by 2019, it had widened significantly, with Republicans consistently more optimistic about job availability than Democrats [1][6]. This trend aligns with increasing polarization in views of Trump’s economic policies, with 79% of Republicans saying his policies have improved economic conditions, compared to only 46% of Democrats [8].

![The partisan gap in job availability perceptions has grown over the years](image5)

In summary, Republicans are significantly more likely than Democrats to perceive job availability positively, and this partisan gap has widened over time, reaching its highest levels in recent years.

Public opinions on Wall Street’s impact on the economy and satisfaction levels with national conditions show stark differences based on political affiliation. 

Republicans are more likely to view Wall Street positively, with 55% believing it helps the U.S. economy more than it harms it, compared to 31% who think otherwise [1]. Democrats, however, are more divided, with 46% saying Wall Street hurts the economy and 41% believing it helps [7]. This partisan divide is further illustrated in `![Views on Wall Street’s impact by political affiliation](image3)`, which shows Republicans leaning toward a positive view while Democrats are split.

Satisfaction with national conditions also reflects deep partisan divisions. Currently, 70% of Americans are dissatisfied with the state of the country, with only 26% expressing satisfaction [3]. Among Republicans, satisfaction has dropped to 47%, the lowest since late 2017, while only 8% of Democrats are satisfied [2][9]. `![Satisfaction with national conditions over time](image1)` highlights this trend, showing a significant decline in satisfaction across the board, particularly in recent years.

In summary, Republicans tend to view Wall Street more favorably and have higher (though declining) satisfaction with national conditions, while Democrats are more critical of Wall Street and overwhelmingly dissatisfied with the state of the nation.

Public satisfaction levels in the U.S. have fluctuated significantly from 1990 to 2019, with a notable decline in recent years. In 2019, 70% of Americans expressed dissatisfaction with the state of the nation, while only 26% were satisfied[1][2][10]. This represents a significant shift from earlier decades, where satisfaction levels were often higher, as seen in the historical trend chart `![Satisfaction levels from 1990 to 2019](image2)`.

Political affiliations have also played a crucial role in shaping these views. In 2019, satisfaction levels were sharply divided along partisan lines. Only 8% of Democrats were satisfied with the state of the nation, compared to 47% of Republicans and Republican leaners[5][6]. However, Republican satisfaction has also declined, dropping 12 percentage points since September 2018[5]. This trend is captured in the historical data `![Satisfaction levels by political affiliation](image5)`, which shows how satisfaction among Democrats and Republicans has shifted over time.

Partisan divisions further extend to views on Wall Street's impact on the economy. Republicans are more likely to believe Wall Street helps the economy (55% vs. 31% who say it hurts)[7], while Democrats are nearly evenly split, with 46% saying it hurts and 41% saying it helps[3]. These differences are highlighted in the survey results `![Views on Wall Street's impact by political affiliation](image4)`. Overall, public dissatisfaction and partisan polarization have deepened over the years, influencing perceptions of both national conditions and economic policies.

Public confidence in Trump’s ability to make good appointments to the federal courts varies significantly between Republicans and Democrats. Among Republicans and Republican-leaning independents, 88% are at least somewhat confident in Trump’s ability in this area, with 64% being very confident [image3]. In contrast, only 2% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents are very confident, and 12% are somewhat confident [image3].

This confidence level in Trump’s ability to make federal court appointments is relatively high among Republicans compared to other tasks. For example, 89% of Republicans are confident in his ability to negotiate favorable trade agreements, and 87% are confident in his ability to manage the executive branch effectively [image3]. However, his lowest confidence rating among Republicans is for working effectively with Congress, where only 70% are at least somewhat confident, and just 31% are very confident [8].

![Public confidence in Trump's ability to make good appointments to the federal courts is much higher among Republicans than Democrats](image3)

In summary, Republicans express strong confidence in Trump’s ability to make federal court appointments, similar to their confidence in his trade negotiation and executive management skills, while Democrats show minimal confidence across these areas.

Confidence levels in Trump’s ability to separate his business interests from presidential decisions vary significantly across political affiliations. Among Republicans, **55%** say they are very confident, and **23%** are somewhat confident, with conservative Republicans (**66%**) being notably more confident than moderate and liberal Republicans (**39%**). In contrast, **69%** of Democrats say they are not at all confident, and **20%** are not too confident, with liberal Democrats being the most skeptical at **83%**. Overall, **28%** of Americans are very confident, while **41%** are not at all confident [4][10][9].
