![Rep/Lean Rep: 55% very confident, 23% somewhat confident | Dem/Lean Dem: 69% not at all confident, 20% not too confident](image3)  

Regarding the perception of Trump’s responsibility to release his tax returns, **64%** of Americans believe he has this responsibility, while **32%** say he does not [8]. Among Republicans, **64%** say he does not have this responsibility, compared to **32%** who say he does [3]. This stark partisan divide is also reflected in Democrats’ skepticism, with **69%** expressing no confidence in Trump’s ability to separate his business interests [2].  

In summary, Republicans are significantly more confident in Trump’s ability to separate his business interests from his presidential decisions, while Democrats are highly skeptical. Similarly, a majority of Americans, including most Democrats, believe Trump has a responsibility to release his tax returns, but most Republicans do not.

Partisan divides significantly shape perceptions of COVID-19 response effectiveness and trust in institutions, with Republicans and Democrats holding starkly different views. Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are less likely to view the U.S. response as more effective compared to other wealthy nations, with only 22% saying it has been more effective, while 34% say it has been less effective. In contrast, 87% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents believe the U.S. response has been less effective than that of other affluent countries [1]. ![Views on U.S. COVID-19 response effectiveness compared to other wealthy nations](image1)

Trust in institutions also varies widely along partisan lines. While positive views of hospitals’ response to COVID-19 are shared across both parties (87% for Republicans and 90% for Democrats), opinions diverge sharply regarding other institutions. For example, only 53% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents give positive ratings to public health officials like those at the CDC, compared to 72% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents [2]. ![Partisan differences in trust toward institutions](image2)

These partisan differences extend to views on the reasons for rising COVID-19 cases. Republicans are less likely than Democrats to attribute the increase in cases to more infections rather than increased testing (30% vs. 77%, respectively) [3]. ![Partisan views on reasons for rising COVID-19 cases](image3)

Over time, trust in public health officials has declined among Republicans, with only 53% approving of their response in August 2020, down from 84% in March. Democrats’ approval of public health officials remained relatively stable at 72% [4]. ![Trends in partisan trust toward public health officials](image5)

In summary, partisan divides profoundly influence perceptions of COVID-19 response effectiveness and trust in institutions, with Republicans generally more critical of public health officials and the U.S. response relative to other countries, while Democrats express higher trust in these institutions but greater dissatisfaction with the overall response.

Partisan differences significantly shape perceptions of the COVID-19 response by public health officials and Donald Trump. Among Republicans, positive assessments of public health officials have plummeted from 84% in March to 53% by August, a 31-point decline [2]. Conversely, Democrats' views remained stable, with 74% in March and 72% in August expressing positive ratings [2][10]. ![Public approval of public health officials has declined sharply among Republicans](image3)

Similarly, Donald Trump’s response to the pandemic is viewed starkly differently across party lines. In March, 56% of Democrats rated Trump’s response as "poor," but this figure rose to 82% by August [9]. Meanwhile, Trump’s approval among Republicans remained relatively unchanged since June, though lower than in March [7]. ![Trump's COVID-19 response ratings show a deepening partisan divide](image3)

The public’s trust in state and local officials has also declined, with steeper drops among Republicans than Democrats [8]. However, perceptions of hospitals’ responses remain consistently positive across both parties, with 88% of the public rating their performance as excellent or good since May [4][6]. ![Hospitals' COVID-19 response remains positively viewed across party lines](image5)

In summary, partisan differences have deepened over time, with Republicans increasingly critical of public health officials and Democrats more disapproving of Trump’s response, while bipartisan support for hospitals remains strong.

Approval ratings for public health officials and Donald Trump have shown significant changes from March to August, with notable partisan differences. 

Public health officials’ approval ratings have declined from 79% in March to 63% in August [1]. This drop is largely driven by Republicans, whose positive assessments fell from 84% to 53% during the same period. In contrast, Democrats’ views remained relatively stable, with 74% approving in March and 72% in August [5]. ![Decline in public health officials' approval among Republicans and stability among Democrats](image4) 

For Donald Trump, his approval ratings for handling the coronavirus outbreak have also decreased. In March, 37% of Americans rated his response as excellent or good, but this figure has since fallen, with 63% now describing his performance as fair or poor [6]. The partisan divide is stark: 77% of Republicans approve of Trump’s performance, while only 5% of Democrats do [2]. Additionally, the share of Democrats who rate Trump’s response as “poor” has risen from 56% in March to 82% in August [8]. ![Sharp decline in Trump's approval ratings, especially among Democrats](image2)

Overall, public health officials’ approval has declined significantly, primarily due to Republicans’ shifting views, while Trump’s ratings have also fallen, driven by increasing disapproval among Democrats. ![Partisan differences in approval ratings for public health officials and Trump](image3)

Americans’ perceptions of state government COVID-19 response differ significantly from their views on Donald Trump’s handling of the pandemic, both in terms of effectiveness and criticism. A majority of U.S. adults (69%) express concern that state governments have been lifting restrictions on public activity too quickly, while only 30% say states have been too slow to lift restrictions[2]. Despite this criticism, public health officials and state/local governments still receive more favorable ratings compared to Trump. For instance, 53% of Republicans give positive ratings to CDC officials, while only 48% rate Trump’s response to the outbreak as “poor”[1][4]. ![Public health officials receive higher ratings than Trump](image1)

When comparing the U.S. response to other affluent nations, Republicans and Democrats diverge sharply. While 34% of Republicans believe the U.S. has been less effective compared to other wealthy countries, 87% of Democrats hold this view[8]. ![Divergent views on the U.S. response compared to other nations](image3) This reflects a broader trend where Democrats are more critical of federal government actions, with 82% citing an inadequate federal response as a major reason for the continued outbreak, compared to only 21% of Republicans[7]. ![Partisan differences in views on the federal response](image4)

In summary, while Americans are critical of both state governments and Trump’s handling of COVID-19, state governments and public health officials receive more favorable assessments compared to the overwhelmingly negative evaluations of Trump’s response.

Americans’ perceptions of the effectiveness in handling COVID-19 vary significantly between elected officials and public health officials. Public health officials, such as those at the CDC, receive more positive evaluations compared to elected officials. About $63\%$ of Americans say public health officials are doing an excellent or good job, though this marks a decline from $79\%$ in March [2]. In contrast, evaluations of state and local government officials have also declined, from $70\%$ to $56\%$ for state officials and from $69\%$ to $60\%$ for local officials [5]. Donald Trump’s response is viewed even more critically, with a majority rating his performance as poor [6].

![Public health officials receive higher positive ratings than elected officials.](image4)

Several factors contribute to the continued outbreak of COVID-19. The most cited reason is that too few people are abiding by guidelines about social distancing and mask-wearing, with $75\%$ of Americans identifying this as a major reason [8]. Lifting restrictions too quickly is also seen as a significant factor, with $58\%$ agreeing it is a major reason [8]. Other contributing factors include inadequate federal government response, insufficient testing, and unclear instructions on preventing the spread [image1]. 

![Major reasons for the continued outbreak include lack of social distancing and mask-wearing, and lifting restrictions too quickly.](image1)

Partisan differences further shape these perceptions. Democrats are more likely than Republicans to view inadequate federal response and lifting restrictions too quickly as major reasons for the outbreak [9]. Overall, while public health officials are viewed more favorably, elected officials face increasing criticism, and the ongoing pandemic is attributed to both individual behaviors and policy decisions.

Political affiliations significantly shape perceptions of government responsibility during the COVID-19 pandemic. A majority of Republicans (68%) believe that state and local governments should be primarily responsible for developing and implementing policies to limit the spread of the virus, while 64% of Democrats argue that the federal government bears most of the responsibility [9]. ![Division of government responsibility](image4)

The continuation of the outbreak is attributed to several factors, with notable partisan differences. Insufficient adherence to social distancing and mask-wearing guidelines is the top reason cited by both parties, though it is more emphasized by Democrats (89%) than Republicans (57%) [3] [5]. ![Factors for the outbreak continuation](image1) 

Democrats are significantly more likely than Republicans to view inadequate federal government response (82% vs. 21%) and lifting COVID-19 restrictions too quickly (82% vs. 31%) as major reasons for the ongoing outbreak [5]. ![Partisan views on outbreak reasons](image5)

In summary, political affiliations influence perceptions of government responsibility and the perceived reasons for the pandemic’s continuation, with Democrats emphasizing federal accountability and systemic failures, while Republicans focus more on individual behavior and state-level governance.

Political affiliations significantly influence perceptions about the reasons for the continued COVID-19 outbreak, particularly regarding government response and social distancing. Democrats and Republicans have starkly differing views on these issues.  

Democrats are far more likely to attribute the outbreak’s continuation to an inadequate federal government response, with 82% citing this as a major reason compared to just 21% of Republicans [5]. Similarly, 82% of Democrats believe that lifting restrictions too quickly is a major factor, while only 31% of Republicans share this view [10].  

![Democrats and Republicans have differing views on the federal government’s role in the outbreak.](image5)  

Both parties, however, agree on the importance of social distancing and mask-wearing. A vast majority of Democrats (90%) and Republicans (57%) see insufficient adherence to these guidelines as a major reason for the outbreak’s continuation, making it the most commonly cited factor overall [6].  

![Both parties agree on the importance of social distancing and mask-wearing as key factors.](image4)  

In summary, while Democrats strongly criticize the federal government’s response and the premature lifting of restrictions, Republicans are less likely to attribute the outbreak to these factors, though both groups largely agree on the significance of social distancing and mask-wearing.

Perceptions of the federal government’s response to the COVID-19 outbreak differ significantly between political affiliations. Democrats are far more critical, with 82% viewing an inadequate federal response as a major reason for the outbreak’s continuation, compared to just 21% of Republicans [1][3]. Additionally, 82% of Democrats believe lifting COVID-19 restrictions too quickly is a major factor, while only 31% of Republicans agree [3][4]. ![Inadequate federal response and lifting restrictions too quickly as major reasons for the outbreak](image1)

The general public cites several major reasons for the continuation of the outbreak. About 53% of Americans point to an inadequate federal government response, 49% to a lack of timely testing, and 40% to unclear instructions on preventing the spread [5]. Insufficient adherence to social distancing and mask-wearing guidelines is also a top reason, with 75% of Democrats and 57% of Republicans considering it a major factor [7][8]. ![Major reasons cited by the public for the continuation of the outbreak](image5)

In summary, Democrats are more likely to blame the federal government’s response and rapid lifting of restrictions, while both parties agree on the importance of social distancing and testing as key factors in the outbreak’s persistence.

Partisan beliefs significantly differ on the reasons for the continuation of the COVID-19 outbreak and the perceived adequacy of measures in place. Republicans and Democrats have contrasting views on several key factors.

**Reasons for the Outbreak’s Continuation:**  
- **Social Distancing and Mask-Wearing:** Majorities in both parties agree that "not enough social distancing" is a major reason for the outbreak continuing, though Democrats (75%) are more likely than Republicans (57%) to hold this view [image3].  
- **Easing Restrictions Too Quickly:** Democrats (82%) are far more likely than Republicans (31%) to say that lifting restrictions too quickly is a major reason for the outbreak’s persistence [5][7].  
- **Inadequate Federal Response:** Democrats (82%) overwhelmingly view an inadequate federal response as a major reason, while only 21% of Republicans agree [7][10].  
- **Testing:** Democrats (67%) are more than twice as likely as Republicans (30%) to say that "not enough timely testing" is a major reason for the outbreak’s continuation [9].  
- **Controllability of the Virus:** Republicans (35%) are more likely than Democrats (20%) to believe that it’s not possible to do much to control the spread [3].

**Perceived Adequacy of Measures:**  
- **Testing vs. Infections:** Republicans (62%) are more likely to attribute the rise in confirmed cases to increased testing rather than new infections, while Democrats (82%) more often attribute it to rising infections [6][8].  
- **Federal vs. Local Government Response:** Democrats are more critical of the federal government’s response compared to Republican views [image5].

![Partisan differences on social distancing, testing, and federal response.](image3)  
![Republicans attribute rising cases to testing, Democrats to infections.](image4)  

In summary, Democrats are more critical of the handling of the pandemic, emphasizing factors like inadequate federal response and early lifting of restrictions, while Republicans are more likely to downplay these factors and attribute case increases to testing rates.

Perspectives on the reasons for rising COVID-19 cases and the lifting of restrictions vary significantly across political affiliations. Democrats overwhelmingly attribute the rise in cases to increased infections rather than more testing, with 80% holding this view [7]. Among Republicans, 62% believe the primary reason for rising cases is increased testing, while 36% attribute it to more infections [6]. ![Republicans and Democrats differ in their views on the cause of rising COVID-19 cases](image1)

When it comes to concerns about lifting restrictions, 93% of liberal Democrats and 88% of conservative and moderate Democrats are more worried that restrictions have been lifted too quickly [1]. By contrast, Republicans are more divided: 53% are concerned that restrictions have not been lifted quickly enough, while 45% worry they have been lifted too quickly. Conservative Republicans lean more toward the former view (60%), while moderate and liberal Republicans are more likely to say restrictions have been lifted too quickly (57%) [8]. ![Partisanship influences concerns about the pace of lifting COVID-19 restrictions](image2)

These differences are also evident in views on why the outbreak continues. For example, 82% of Democrats believe easing restrictions too quickly is a major reason, compared to only 31% of Republicans [9]. ![Democrats are more likely than Republicans to view lifting restrictions too quickly as a major reason for the ongoing outbreak](image5) 

Overall, the partisan divide is stark, with Democrats emphasizing rising infections and swift lifting of restrictions as key factors, while Republicans focus more on increased testing and advocate for faster reopening.

Views on the causes of increased COVID-19 cases and opinions on lifting restrictions are deeply divided along partisan lines. Republicans and Democrats have markedly different perspectives on these issues, reflecting broader ideological divides.

![Republicans are more likely to attribute increased cases to testing, while Democrats see new infections as the primary cause.](image5) A majority of Republicans (62%) believe that the rise in confirmed COVID-19 cases is primarily due to more people being tested, while only 36% attribute it to new infections [5]. In contrast, Democrats overwhelmingly (80%) view increased infections as the main cause [9]. This divide is also visible within Republican subgroups, with conservative Republicans more likely to emphasize testing (66%) compared to moderate and liberal Republicans, who are split (53% testing vs. 45% infections) [5].

![Democrats are more concerned than Republicans about restrictions being lifted too quickly.](image1) These differing views on the causes of increased cases align with attitudes toward lifting restrictions. Democrats are far more likely (82%) to see restrictions being lifted too quickly as a major reason for the ongoing outbreak, compared to only 31% of Republicans [3][6]. Similarly, 93% of liberal Democrats and 88% of conservative/moderate Democrats express concern that restrictions have been lifted too quickly, while 53% of Republicans worry more about restrictions not being lifted quickly enough [1][2]. This gap is particularly pronounced among conservative Republicans, 60% of whom prioritize lifting restrictions faster [1].

![The partisan divide extends to concerns about inadequate federal response and other factors contributing to the outbreak.](image3) Beyond restrictions, Democrats are more likely than Republicans to cite inadequate federal response (82% vs. 21%) and insufficient testing (67% vs. 30%) as major reasons for the outbreak’s continuation [6]. These differences underscore how political affiliation shapes perceptions of both the causes of the pandemic and the effectiveness of policy responses.

In summary, Republicans tend to attribute increased COVID-19 cases to more testing and favor faster lifting of restrictions, while Democrats believe new infections are the primary cause and are more concerned about restrictions being lifted too quickly.

Views on requiring government-issued photo identification to vote vary significantly across racial groups and political affiliations. Among Democrats, support for this policy is higher among Black (65%), Hispanic (72%), and Asian (71%) Democrats compared to White Democrats (54%)[2]. ![White Democrats show 54% support, while Black, Hispanic, and Asian Democrats show higher support at 65%, 72%, and 71%, respectively.](image2) 

Republicans, on the other hand, overwhelmingly support this policy, with 93% in favor[3]. However, within the Republican party, White adults are less supportive of this policy compared to Hispanic Republicans, though specific data for Black and Asian Republicans is limited due to sample size[7].

Overall, Black adults show the lowest levels of support for restrictive policies like requiring photo ID, reflecting broader skepticism toward such measures[8]. ![Black adults are less supportive of restrictive voting policies, including photo ID requirements.](image1) 

These differences highlight a racial divide in attitudes toward voting policies, with minority groups often demonstrating higher support for measures that may enhance voting access, even though they are more likely to face barriers to obtaining photo IDs[4][6]. ![White adults are less likely to support policies like making Election Day a national holiday compared to Black, Hispanic, and Asian adults.](image3) 

In summary, while both Democrats and Republicans show significant support for requiring photo ID to vote, the level of support varies by race and political affiliation, with minority Democrats and Republicans expressing notably higher or lower support compared to their White counterparts.

Racial and ethnic differences significantly shape support for various voting policies. Black adults are notably more likely than White, Hispanic, and Asian adults to favor expansive voting policies, such as 'no excuse' early or absentee voting [1] and allowing people convicted of felonies to vote after serving their sentences—85% of Black Americans support this, compared to about 70% of White, Hispanic, and Asian Americans [6]. ![Black Americans show strong support for expansive voting policies](image1)

When it comes to requiring government-issued photo identification, Black adults show among the lowest levels of support, contrasting with higher support among Hispanic (72%) and Asian (71%) adults [4]. ![Hispanic and Asian Americans show higher support for photo ID requirements](image5) White adults, particularly Republicans, are less supportive of policies aimed at easing voting, such as automatically registering all eligible citizens to vote—35% of White Republicans support this, compared to 51% of Hispanic Republicans [7]. ![White Republicans show less support for automatic voter registration](image2)

Partisanship also plays a role, with only 38% of Republicans favoring allowing all voters to vote early or absentee, compared to higher support among Democrats [8]. Among Democrats, White adults are often as supportive or more supportive than Black, Hispanic, and Asian adults of policies making it easier to vote [9]. ![Partisanship influences views on early and absentee voting](image4)

In summary, Black adults are more likely to support expansive voting policies like early or absentee voting, while Hispanic and Asian adults are more likely to favor stricter measures like photo ID requirements. White adults, especially Republicans, are less supportive of policies aimed at easing voting access.

White Democrats (54%) show lower support for requiring government-issued photo identification to vote compared to Black (65%), Hispanic (72%), and Asian Democrats (71%) [6]. This pattern is illustrated in the data with White Democrats at 54%, Black Democrats at 65%, Hispanic Democrats at 72%, and Asian Democrats at 71% ![Support for photo ID requirement among Democrats](image2). Among Republicans, there is a strong majority favoring photo identification requirements (81% strongly favor), with less variation across racial and ethnic groups [9]. 

In contrast, White adults, regardless of party, are less supportive of expansive voting accessibility policies compared to Black, Hispanic, and Asian adults. For example, Hispanic Republicans (51%) are more supportive of automatic voter registration than White Republicans (35%) [3]. Black adults are particularly distinctive in their preference for inclusive policies, such as allowing people convicted of felonies to vote after serving their sentences, with 85% in favor compared to about 70% of White, Hispanic, and Asian Americans [7]. 

Overall, while majorities across racial and political groups favor policies like early voting and paper backups for electronic voting machines [10], significant disparities exist in support for more restrictive measures like photo ID requirements, with Black adults showing the lowest levels of support for such policies [5]. ![Support for early voting policies across demographics](image5). 

In summary, racial and political affiliations significantly shape perspectives on photo ID requirements and voting accessibility policies, with White adults generally less supportive of expansive measures and more supportive of restrictive ones compared to Black, Hispanic, and Asian adults.

Political and demographic groups exhibit varying perspectives on independent redistricting and early absentee voting options. When it comes to independent redistricting, nearly half of U.S. adults approve of a proposal by House Democrats to create bipartisan redistricting commissions, while only 13% disapprove and 38% are unsure [8]. This suggests broad but cautious support across the population, though partisanship likely plays a role in shaping these views. ![Nearly half of U.S. adults approve of independent redistricting commissions](image2)

On the issue of early and absentee voting, partisanship remains a significant factor. Only 38% of Republicans favor allowing all voters to vote early or absentee without a documented reason, compared to 84% of Democrats [3][7]. This divide is further emphasized by recent voting experiences: Republicans who voted absentee in 2020 are more supportive of no-excuse absentee or early voting than those who voted in person [1][5]. ![Partisanship significantly influences support for no-excuse absentee voting](image4)

Demographic differences also emerge. White Democrats are more supportive of early or absentee voting than Democrats of other races and ethnicities, while White Republicans are less supportive compared to Hispanic Republicans [2]. Additionally, ideological differences within the GOP are stark: 70% of conservative Republicans believe documented reasons should be required for absentee voting, while moderates and liberals are evenly split [9]. ![Demographic and ideological differences shape views on early absentee voting](image1)

In summary, support for independent redistricting is cautiously positive, while views on early absentee voting are deeply divided along partisan, ideological, and demographic lines.

Different political affiliations hold varying views on voting methods and redistricting proposals, as revealed by the data. 

Regarding redistricting, nearly half of U.S. adults approve of a proposal to establish bipartisan redistricting commissions, with 50% in favor and 13% opposed. However, Republicans and Republican leaners are more likely to disapprove of such commissions (19%) compared to Democrats (8%), and they are also more unsure about the proposal (42% vs. 32%) [3] [8].

When it comes to voting methods, Republican voters who cast their ballots early or absentee are more supportive of no-excuse absentee or early voting (52%) compared to those who voted in person on Election Day (22%) [7] [10]. This trend is less pronounced among Democrats, where support for no-excuse voting remains consistently high across voting methods [6] [7]. Additionally, ideological divides exist within the Republican Party: 70% of conservative Republicans believe voters should provide documented reasons for absentee or early voting, while only 30% think it should be unnecessary. Among moderate and liberal Republicans, opinions are more evenly split [9].

Visualizing these trends, ![Views on redistricting proposals vary by political affiliation, with Republicans more likely to disapprove or be unsure](image5). ![Support for no-excuse absentee voting is higher among Republicans who voted absentee compared to those who voted in person](image3). 

In summary, while there is broad support for bipartisan redistricting commissions, Republicans are more divided on the issue. Similarly, Republicans who have recently voted absentee are more likely to support no-excuse absentee or early voting, reflecting a divide within the party based on voting experience and ideology.

The views of Republicans and Democrats regarding 'no excuse' early or absentee voting and automatically registering all eligible citizens to vote have shifted significantly since 2018. Republicans have become less supportive of 'no excuse' early or absentee voting, with the share favoring this policy dropping from 57% in 2018 to 38% in 2021 [5]. This decline is also evident in the graphic representation, which shows a sharp decrease in Republican support for this policy over the years ![Sharp decline in Republican support for 'no excuse' early or absentee voting](image2). Conversely, Democrats have maintained strong support for 'no excuse' early or absentee voting, with 84% favoring this policy in 2021, virtually unchanged from previous years [5].

Regarding automatic voter registration, Republicans have also become less supportive, with the share favoring this policy decreasing from 49% in 2018 to 38% in 2021 [7]. ![Decline in Republican support for automatic voter registration](image3) In contrast, Democrats have consistently supported automatic voter registration, with 82% in favor in 2021, remaining stable over the years [1].

In summary, Republican support for 'no excuse' early or absentee voting and automatic voter registration has declined since 2018, while Democratic support for these policies has remained consistently high.

From 2018 to 2021, partisan views on making Election Day a national holiday and requiring photo ID to vote have shown some notable shifts. Democrats have become 7 percentage points more likely to favor making Election Day a national holiday compared to 2018, while Republicans remain about as likely to support this policy as they were in 2018 [1]. Younger Republicans (18-34 years old) are significantly more supportive of making Election Day a holiday (71%) compared to older Republicans (65+, 50%) [3]. ![Younger Republicans are more supportive of making Election Day a national holiday](image4)

In contrast, views on requiring government-issued photo ID to vote have remained largely unchanged since 2018. Republicans continue to overwhelmingly support this policy (93% in 2021) [6]. Democrats, however, are much less likely to strongly favor photo ID requirements (30% in 2021 compared to 81% of Republicans) [4]. ![Republicans overwhelmingly support photo ID requirements for voting](image5)

Overall, while Democrats have moved toward greater support for making Election Day a holiday, Republicans’ stance on this issue remains steady. Meanwhile, both parties’ positions on photo ID requirements have seen little change, with Republicans consistently showing stronger support.

Latino voters’ party affiliations and key election issues have shown notable trends from 2019 to 2022. In terms of party identification, Latino registered voters have consistently leaned toward the Democratic Party over the Republican Party by a nearly two-to-one margin. In 2022, 64% identified with or leaned toward the Democratic Party, compared to 33% for the Republican Party, a pattern that has remained relatively stable over the years [2]. However, about one-in-five Latino voters (18%) remain uncertain or support another candidate, indicating some fluidity in party loyalty [9]. ![Latino registered voters' party identification over time](image2)

The importance of key election issues has also shifted. The economy remains the top issue for Latino voters, with 80% considering it very important in the 2022 midterms, unchanged since March [10]. Other critical issues include health care (71%), violent crime and education (70% each), and gun policy (66%). However, abortion has seen the most significant rise in importance, increasing from 42% in March to 57% in August 2022, likely due to the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade [8]. ![Latino voters' evolving priorities on key issues](image3)

Demographic factors also influence preferences. Hispanic voters who consider their identity extremely or very important are more likely to support the Democratic candidate (60%) [7]. Religiosity also plays a role, with Catholics and Evangelical Protestants showing varied party leanings. ![Latino voters' party affiliation by religious affiliation](image4) Additionally, political ideology within party affiliations differs: among Democratic-leaning Latinos, conservatives and moderates outnumber liberals, while Republican-leaning Latinos are predominantly conservative. ![Detailed breakdown of Latino voters' party affiliation](image1)

In summary, Latino voters’ party affiliations have remained largely consistent, with a strong Democratic lean, while issues like abortion have gained prominence. Demographic factors such as identity importance, religiosity, and ideology further shape their political preferences.

The views of Hispanic Democrats and Republicans differ significantly regarding the future political role of Trump and the perception of racial discrimination. 

A clear majority of Hispanic registered voters (73%) say they would not like to see Trump remain a national political figure, including nearly all Latino Democrats and Democratic leaners (94%). In contrast, 63% of Hispanic Republicans and GOP leaners say they would like to see Trump remain a national political figure, with about four-in-ten (41%) supporting his potential run for president in 2024 [7]. ![Majority of Hispanic Democrats oppose Trump’s continued political role, while a significant portion of Hispanic Republicans support it](image4)

On the issue of racial discrimination, nearly three-quarters of Latino Democrats and Democratic leaners (73%) say people not seeing racial discrimination where it really does exist is a bigger problem. Conversely, about six-in-ten Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners (62%) believe it is a bigger problem that people see racial discrimination where it really does not exist [1]. ![Latino Democrats emphasize the underrecognition of racial discrimination, while Republicans focus on overrecognition](image5)

These differences highlight the partisan divide among Hispanics on both Trump’s political future and the perception of racial discrimination.

Hispanic registered voters' views on Trump's political future are closely tied to their party affiliations, concerns about racial discrimination, and stances on gun rights. A clear majority of Hispanic registered voters (73%) say they would not like to see Trump remain a national political figure, with nearly all Latino Democrats and Democratic leaners (94%) opposing this. In contrast, 63% of Hispanic Republicans and GOP leaners support Trump remaining a national figure, including 41% who believe he should run for president in 2024 [6].

These views are also influenced by concerns about racial discrimination. Among Latinos, more Democrats than Republicans see the failure to recognize racial discrimination as a significant problem. This is reflected in the sharp divide in attitudes toward Trump, who has been a polarizing figure in discussions about race and equality since George Floyd's killing in May 2020 [9][10]. ![Latino views on Trump's political future](image4)

On gun policy, Hispanics are generally more likely to prioritize controlling gun ownership (73%) over protecting the right to own guns (26%). Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners (85%) are especially supportive of gun control, while Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners (45%) are more divided on the issue [7]. This policy stance aligns with the broader trend of Hispanic Democrats being more critical of Trump and his policies, including those related to gun rights. ![Hispanic views on gun policy](image3)

In summary, Hispanic registered voters' opposition to Trump's political future is strongly linked to their concerns about racial discrimination and their support for gun control, particularly among Democrats. Republicans, however, are more likely to support Trump and prioritize gun rights.

Among Hispanic registered voters, views on Donald Trump’s political future and perceptions of racial discrimination are sharply divided along party lines. A clear majority of Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners (94%) say they do not want Trump to remain a national political figure, while 63% of Hispanic Republicans and GOP leaners support his continued political involvement, with 41% specifically advocating for him to run for president in 2024 [6][7]. This stark contrast is further highlighted in the data, which shows that only 25% of all Latino registered voters want Trump to remain a national political figure, with the majority of this support coming from Republican-leaning Latinos (68%) [7]. ![Majority of Hispanic Democrats oppose Trump's political future, while Republicans support it](image5)

On the issue of racial discrimination, Hispanic Democrats and Republicans also diverge significantly. Nearly three-quarters of Latino Democrats and Democratic leaners (73%) believe that people not seeing racial discrimination where it truly exists is a bigger problem. In contrast, about six-in-ten Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners (62%) argue that the bigger issue is people seeing racial discrimination where it does not exist [10]. This split reflects broader ideological differences within the Latino community regarding how racial discrimination is perceived and addressed. ![Hispanic Democrats and Republicans differ on perceptions of racial discrimination](image2)

Hispanic perceptions of socialism and capitalism vary significantly by political affiliation and age groups. 

Among Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners, 68% have a positive view of capitalism, compared to 50% of Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners [1]. This suggests a clear partisan divide in attitudes toward capitalism. When it comes to socialism, Hispanic Democrats are split almost evenly (48% negative vs. 50% positive), while Hispanic Republicans lean more negatively [8]. ![Hispanic views of socialism and capitalism by political affiliation](image3)

Age also plays a role in shaping these perceptions. Younger Latinos (ages 18-29) are more divided in their views of socialism, with 46% reporting a positive impression and 50% a negative one. This pattern is similar among Latinos aged 30-49. However, majorities of older Latinos (ages 50-64 and 65+) hold negative views of socialism, with 60% and 61% respectively expressing disapproval [5][6]. ![Hispanic views of socialism by age group](image5)

Across all age groups, Hispanics generally have a more positive view of capitalism than socialism. For example, 54% of Hispanics have a positive impression of capitalism, compared to 41% for socialism [2][7]. This aligns with the broader U.S. public, where 57% of adults view capitalism positively [4]. ![Hispanic views of capitalism](image1)

In summary, Hispanic Republicans are more favorable toward capitalism than Hispanic Democrats, and younger Hispanics are more open to socialism than older Hispanics.

Hispanic views on socialism and capitalism vary significantly based on political affiliation. Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners are nearly evenly split in their views of socialism, with 48% viewing it negatively and 50% positively [4]. In contrast, Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners have a much more negative view of socialism, with 68% expressing a positive view of capitalism compared to only 50% of Hispanic Democrats [6].  

![Hispanics' views on socialism and capitalism vary by political affiliation, with Republicans favoring capitalism more than Democrats.](image1)  

When it comes to capitalism, Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners are more divided, with 50% having a positive view, while Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners show stronger support at 68% [6]. This aligns with broader trends where Hispanic Republicans tend to align more closely with capitalist ideals, while Hispanic Democrats exhibit a more nuanced or mixed perspective.  

![Hispanic Republicans are significantly more supportive of capitalism compared to Hispanic Democrats.](image6)  

Overall, the data highlights a clear partisan divide among Hispanics, with Republicans leaning more positively toward capitalism and Democrats being more divided in their views on socialism. This reflects broader trends in the U.S., where political affiliation strongly shapes economic perspectives. Hispanic views on socialism and capitalism are more polarized along party lines, with Republicans favoring capitalism and Democrats showing greater openness to socialism.

Perceptions of political parties’ efforts to earn Latino votes vary significantly across demographic groups, revealing a complex political landscape. ![A breakdown of Latino demographics](image1)  

A substantial share of Latino immigrants, Spanish speakers, Catholics, and evangelicals believe that Democrats work hard to earn their votes [2]. For instance, 44% of immigrants, 48% of Spanish-dominant Latinos, and 42% of Catholics and evangelicals say this [9]. Democrats are seen as more actively engaging with these groups, as opposed to Republicans. ![All Hispanics with political leanings](image2)  

In contrast, only 19% of Latinos overall believe that Republicans work hard to earn their votes, with this perception varying among subgroups. For example, 23% of immigrants, 24% of Spanish-dominant Latinos, and 27% of evangelicals share this view [6]. Among Latino Republicans, 40% feel that Republicans work hard to earn Latino votes, compared to just 13% of Latino Democrats [3]. ![All Hispanics with demographic breakdowns](image3)  

This suggests a stark partisan divide. While Democrats are perceived as making concerted efforts to engage Latino voters, Republicans are viewed as less active in this regard. This is further emphasized by the fact that 47% of Latino Republicans and Republican-leaning conservatives believe Democrats do not work hard to earn their votes, indicating a lack of trust in the opposing party [4]. ![Net perceptions of party efforts](image4)  

These perceptions likely influence voting behavior and party loyalty. For example, 54% of Hispanic Democrats and 57% of Hispanic Republicans see a great deal of difference between the parties, while smaller shares of independent leaners (35% Democratic, 39% Republican) share this view [1]. This polarization suggests that party identity and engagement efforts play a significant role in shaping Latino political attitudes. ![Detailed breakdown of perceptions](image5)  

In summary, Democrats are generally perceived as more effective in engaging Latino voters, while Republicans face skepticism, particularly among non-partisan and Democratic-leaning Latinos. This dynamic underscores the importance of targeted outreach in shaping the political landscape.

Latino voters' perceptions of the Democratic and Republican parties' efforts to engage with them vary significantly based on their political affiliations. Among Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners, 56% believe the Democratic Party works hard to earn Latinos’ votes, compared to only 35% of Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners who say the same about the Republican Party [1]. Similarly, 36% of Latino Republicans view the Democratic Party as genuinely caring about Latinos, while just 21% of Latino Democrats feel the same about the Republican Party [8].

These perceptions are reflected in party affiliation trends, where Latino registered voters predominantly lean Democratic by a two-to-one margin (64% vs. 33%) [2]. ![Latino party identification remains largely unchanged in recent years](image10). Over the years, this gap has remained consistent, with Latino voters continuing to favor the Democratic Party [2]. ![Latino party affiliation trends show a stable Democratic lead from 2019 to 2022](image2).

Additionally, substantial minorities within both parties hold favorable views of the opposing party. For example, 36% of Latino Republicans and 21% of Latino Democrats acknowledge the opposing party’s efforts to care about Latinos [7]. ![Latino Republicans are more likely to see the Democratic Party as caring about Latinos than vice versa](image5). Despite this, a significant portion of Latinos (45%) perceive a great deal of difference between the two parties, with nearly equal shares of Hispanic Democrats (47%) and Republicans (48%) holding this view [5]. ![Perceptions of differences between the parties vary among Latino voters](image3).

These dynamics highlight a nuanced landscape where Latino voters’ perceptions of party engagement influence, but do not drastically alter, their party affiliations. The Democratic Party continues to hold a significant advantage among Latino voters, though the Republican Party has made some inroads through its perceived efforts to engage with the community. ![Latino voters' views on party engagement reflect ongoing political trends](image4).

Perceptions of party differences and support for political parties among Hispanics show notable trends over time and vary by political affiliation. According to the 2022 National Survey of Latinos, fewer than half of Hispanics (45%) see a great deal of difference between the Democratic and Republican parties, while 36% say there is a fair amount of difference, and 16% see hardly any difference at all [1][6]. These perceptions are relatively consistent across party lines, with 47% of Hispanic Democrats/Democratic leaners and 48% of Hispanic Republicans/Republican leaners acknowledging a great deal of difference between the parties [6].

![Fewer than half of Hispanics perceive significant differences between the parties](image5)

Support for political parties also varies by affiliation. Latino registered voters identify with or lean toward the Democratic Party over the Republican Party by a nearly two-to-one margin (64% vs. 33%) [8]. This preference has remained stable in recent years, with little change in party identification [10]. 

![Latino party identification has remained stable over the years](image2)

Latinos generally hold more positive views of the Democratic Party compared to the GOP. For example, 71% of Latinos say the Democratic Party works hard for their votes, and 63% believe it “really cares about Latinos,” while only 45% say the same about the Republican Party [9]. These sentiments are reflected in detailed breakdowns by party affiliation: Democratic leaners express higher approval of the Democratic Party’s efforts to engage Latinos, while Republican leaners show greater support for the GOP [image1][image4].

![Latinos view the Democratic Party more positively than the GOP](image1)

Finally, Latinos’ perceptions of key issues, such as the economy, health care, and immigration, influence their views of the parties. The Democratic Party is seen as more aligned with Latinos’ priorities on these issues, which contributes to its stronger support among this demographic [3][image3]. 

![Key issues like the economy and health care shape Latinos’ party preferences](image3)

In summary, while Hispanic perceptions of party differences remain divided, support for political parties is heavily skewed toward the Democratic Party, with consistent trends in party identification and issue alignment shaping these views over time.

Latino voters' views on the differences between the Democratic and Republican parties have shown limited change in recent years, with a significant portion not perceiving a stark contrast between the two. About 45% of Hispanics see a great deal of difference between the parties, while 36% see a fair amount, and 16% see hardly any difference at all [1]. ![A chart showing perceptions of differences between the parties among all Hispanics, Democrats/leaners, and Republicans/leaners](image1). This sentiment is consistent across both Hispanic Democrats/Democratic leaners (47%) and Hispanic Republicans/Republican leaners (48%) [1]. 

Despite these perceptions, Latino voters continue to lean more heavily toward the Democratic Party, with 64% identifying as Democrats or leaning Democratic compared to 33% for the Republican Party in 2022 [6]. ![A line graph showing the stability of Latino party affiliation from 2019 to 2022](image2). This preference has remained relatively stable over the past few years, with little significant shift in party identification [2]. However, a 2021 Pew Research study found that a substantial share of Latino voters have soft ties to political parties, suggesting potential for future shifts in affiliation [10].

These views may influence their voting behavior, as Latino voters prioritize issues like the economy (80%), health care (71%), and education (70%) when deciding who to vote for in congressional elections [3]. ![A bar chart showing the importance of various issues to Latino voters in 2022](image5). Additionally, perceptions of how much the parties care about Latinos and work to earn their votes vary significantly. For instance, 78% of Democrat-leaning Latino voters feel the Democratic Party "really cares about Latinos," compared to just 36% of Republican-leaning voters who feel the same about the GOP [3]. ![A detailed breakdown of Latino voters' views on how well the parties represent their interests](image3). Similarly, 71% of Latino voters believe the Democratic Party "works hard to earn Latinos’ votes," while only 45% say the same about the Republican Party [4].

In summary, while Latino voters’ perception of the differences between the parties has not changed significantly, their strong Democratic leaning persists. However, their focus on key issues and soft partisan ties could make their future party affiliation uncertain.

Men and women in STEM jobs share some common values, but there are notable differences in what they prioritize in their careers. Both genders place high importance on having flexibility to balance work and family obligations, with 71% of men and 76% of women valuing this characteristic similarly [text 9] ![Men and women in STEM value flexibility similarly](image1). However, men tend to emphasize higher pay and opportunities for promotion more than women, with 57% of men valuing promotion opportunities compared to 46% of women, and 48% of men prioritizing high-paying jobs compared to 39% of women ![Men in STEM value higher pay and promotion more than women](image1). In contrast, women in STEM are more likely to value jobs that focus on helping others, with 59% of women considering this important compared to 31% of men [text 9] ![Women in STEM value helping others more than men](image1). Additionally, women are more inclined to seek jobs that make a meaningful contribution to society and are respected, with 50% of women valuing this compared to 43% of men ![Women in STEM value meaningful contributions and respect more than men](image1). These differences highlight how gender influences the characteristics valued in STEM careers.

Men and women in STEM jobs share some common preferences, such as valuing flexibility to balance work and family obligations. However, there are notable differences in other job characteristics they prioritize. Men in STEM are more likely to value higher pay (57% vs. 48%) and opportunities for promotion (57% vs. 46%) compared to women [7]. On the other hand, women in STEM are significantly more inclined to value jobs that help others (59% vs. 31%) and make a meaningful contribution to society (51% vs. 43%) [7] ![Men value higher pay and promotion opportunities more, while women prioritize jobs that help others](image4).

These differences in values align with some of the barriers women face in entering and succeeding in STEM. For instance, women in STEM are more likely to report experiencing gender discrimination, which affects recruitment, hiring, and promotions. About 48% of women in STEM view this as a major reason for the underrepresentation of women in the field, compared to 29% of men [10] ![Gender discrimination is a major barrier for women in STEM](image3). Additionally, women in STEM often face challenges like pay gaps and unequal treatment rooted in gender stereotypes, which may discourage their pursuit of STEM careers [3].

Another factor is the lack of encouragement for girls to pursue STEM from an early age, which 39% of Americans consider a major reason for the low representation of women in STEM [5]. This lack of early encouragement, combined with fewer female role models in STEM, can make these fields seem less accessible or welcoming to women [3] ![Lack of early encouragement and role models hinders women in STEM](image3).

In summary, while men and women in STEM both value flexibility, men prioritize pay and promotion, whereas women place greater emphasis on jobs that help others. These differences, coupled with gender discrimination and insufficient early encouragement, contribute to the challenges women face in entering and thriving in STEM careers.

The underrepresentation of women and blacks and Hispanics in STEM jobs is driven by several factors, which differ between these groups. 

![Major reasons for the lack of women and minorities in STEM jobs](image1)  

For **women**, the primary reasons include discrimination in recruitment, hiring, and promotions, with 48% of women in STEM jobs viewing this as a major issue compared to 29% of men [3]. Another significant factor is the lack of encouragement to pursue STEM from an early age, cited by 39% of Americans [6]. Women also face challenges balancing work and family, a lack of female role models, and a perception that they are less likely to succeed in STEM fields [image1]. 

For **blacks and Hispanics**, the lack of access to quality education to prepare for STEM fields is a major reason, with 42% of Americans and a majority of black STEM workers (73%) highlighting this issue [7, 9]. Discrimination in recruitment, hiring, and promotions is also a key factor, with 72% of blacks in STEM viewing this as a major reason, compared to 27% of whites and 28% of Asians [5, 8]. Additionally, the absence of black and Hispanic role models in STEM and the lack of early encouragement are significant barriers [image1]. 

In summary, while both groups face discrimination and lack of early encouragement, women in STEM are more impacted by work-family balance and the absence of female role models, whereas blacks and Hispanics are disproportionately affected by limited access to quality education and the scarcity of minority role models.

STEM workers tend to have significantly higher levels of education compared to non-STEM workers, which influences the types of employment sectors they predominantly work in. Overall, STEM workers are about twice as likely as non-STEM workers to have earned at least a bachelor’s degree (65% vs. 32%), and nearly three-in-ten (29%) have earned a master’s, doctorate, or professional degree, far exceeding the share of non-STEM workers with advanced degrees (12%) [7]. ![STEM workers have higher educational attainment compared to non-STEM workers.](image2)

This higher educational attainment aligns with the fact that most STEM workers (66%) are employed in the private, for-profit sector, mirroring the overall employment distribution. However, within STEM fields, engineers and architects (82%) and computer workers (77%) are particularly concentrated in private, for-profit roles, while fewer healthcare practitioners and technicians (58%) work in this sector. In contrast, almost a quarter of healthcare practitioners and technicians (23%) work for not-for-profit employers [8]. ![STEM employment sectors show a strong presence in private, for-profit industries.](image4)

Additionally, STEM workers are less likely to be self-employed (6%) compared to non-STEM workers (11%), indicating a preference for structured employment environments that often require advanced education and specialized training [10]. ![STEM workers are less likely to be self-employed compared to non-STEM workers.](image4)

In summary, STEM workers' higher educational levels correlate with their concentration in private, for-profit sectors, particularly in engineering and computer-related fields, while being less prevalent in self-employed roles compared to non-STEM workers.

STEM workers tend to have significantly higher levels of education compared to non-STEM workers. About 65% of STEM workers have earned at least a bachelor’s degree, which is nearly double the 32% of non-STEM workers with similar qualifications [6]. Additionally, 29% of STEM workers hold a master’s, doctorate, or professional degree, far exceeding the 12% of non-STEM workers with advanced degrees [6]. Some college education, including associate degrees, is also common among STEM workers, particularly in healthcare, computer, and engineering fields [9]. 

![The majority of STEM workers hold at least a bachelor's degree, while non-STEM workers are more likely to have lower educational attainment.](image2)

In terms of employment sectors, the majority of STEM workers (66%) are employed in private, for-profit companies, similar to the overall workforce [4]. However, there are variations within STEM fields: engineers and architects (82%) and computer workers (77%) are more likely to work in the private sector, while nearly a quarter of healthcare practitioners and technicians (23%) work for not-for-profit employers [4]. Self-employment is less common among STEM workers (6%) compared to non-STEM workers (11%) [3]. 

![STEM employment is predominantly in the private sector, with variations across different fields.](image3)

Over time, the representation of women in STEM has increased, particularly in life and physical sciences, but they remain underrepresented in computer and engineering roles [10]. Racial and ethnic diversity in STEM also varies, with Black and Hispanic workers underrepresented overall and Asians overrepresented, particularly in computer occupations [7][8]. 

![Women's representation in STEM has grown over time, but disparities remain in certain fields.](image1) ![Asians are overrepresented in STEM, especially in computer-related roles.](image4) ![Healthcare-related STEM jobs have seen significant growth in female representation.](image5)

In summary, STEM workers are more highly educated than non-STEM workers, and their employment is concentrated in the private sector with some variation across fields. Over time, there have been shifts in the demographics of STEM workers, but certain disparities persist.

Discrimination experiences in STEM jobs vary significantly among racial groups and between genders. Black STEM employees report the highest levels of racial discrimination, with 62% stating they have experienced such discrimination at work, compared to 44% of Asians, 42% of Hispanics, and 13% of whites [3][5]. Black STEM workers are also more likely to feel there is insufficient attention to racial diversity in their workplaces (57%) and to believe they are treated unfairly in opportunities for advancement (24%) [10].

![Black STEM workers report the highest levels of racial discrimination.](image5)

Gender-based discrimination is also prevalent, particularly for women in STEM. Half of women in STEM report experiencing gender discrimination, compared to 19% of men [6]. This disparity is especially pronounced in majority-male workplaces, computer jobs, and among those with postgraduate degrees [2]. Common forms of gender discrimination include earning less than men in the same role (29%), being treated as incompetent (29%), and experiencing repeated slights (20%) [6].

![Women in STEM report higher gender discrimination compared to men.](image2)

Moreover, in workplaces with more men, 78% of women in STEM have experienced gender-related discrimination, and 48% feel their gender has made it harder to succeed [image1]. Gender disparities are even more pronounced in computer jobs, where 74% of women report gender-related discrimination, compared to 16% of men [image3].

In summary, Black STEM workers face the most severe racial discrimination, while women in STEM, particularly in male-dominated fields, experience significant gender-based discrimination. These trends highlight ongoing challenges in achieving equity in STEM workplaces.

Women in STEM jobs working in male-dominated environments experience significantly more workplace discrimination and gender inequities compared to those in more gender-balanced settings. According to the data, **78% of women in majority-male workplaces report experiencing gender discrimination**, compared to **43% of women in majority-female workplaces** [6][8]. ![78% of women in majority-male workplaces report gender discrimination](image1)  

Additionally, women in male-dominated settings are far more likely to feel that their gender has made it harder to succeed in their job (**48%** vs. **12% in majority-female workplaces**) [8]. ![48% of women in male-dominated STEM workplaces feel their gender hinders success](image4)  

Women in these environments also report higher levels of subtle discrimination, such as being treated as if they are not competent, experiencing repeated slights, and receiving less support from senior leaders compared to their male counterparts [9]. ![Women in STEM are more likely to experience workplace discrimination than men](image2)  

In contrast, women in more gender-balanced settings feel less isolated and are less likely to perceive their gender as a barrier to success. They also report fewer instances of needing to prove themselves to gain respect from coworkers [3][7].  

Overall, the gender balance in the workplace plays a critical role in shaping women’s experiences, with male-dominated environments exacerbating feelings of inequity and discrimination. ![Women in male-dominated STEM workplaces face more discrimination and inequities](image4)

The self-identification of Hispanics in the U.S. varies significantly across generations and is influenced by a combination of cultural, linguistic, and familial factors. For immigrant Hispanics (first generation), **36%** consider themselves typical Americans, while this figure rises to **63%** for second-generation Hispanics and **73%** for third or higher generations, reflecting their U.S. birth and lifetime experiences[7]. This generational shift is also evident in linguistic identity. While **58%** of immigrant Latinos believe speaking Spanish is not required to be considered Latino, this view is even more pronounced among U.S.-born Latinos, with **84%** of second-generation and **92%** of third or higher generation Latinos sharing the same sentiment[6].  

Another factor is the importance of a Spanish last name, with **84%** of self-identified Hispanics saying it is not essential to their identity[4]. However, for adults with Hispanic ancestry who do not self-identify as Hispanic, **81%** say they have never considered themselves Hispanic, often citing reasons such as mixed backgrounds, limited contact with Hispanic relatives, or a lack of cultural links[10].  

These trends are visualized in the generation-specific breakdowns:  
![Self-identification trends across generations](image1)  

The reasons for not self-identifying as Hispanic are multifaceted, with **27%** attributing it to mixed backgrounds or distant ancestry, **16%** to upbringing or lack of contact with Hispanic relatives, **15%** to a lack of Spanish proficiency or cultural ties, **12%** to identifying as another race or not looking Hispanic, and **9%** to being born in the U.S. and identifying as American[10].  
![Reasons for not self-identifying as Hispanic](image2)  

Additionally, the broader racial and ethnic identity framework in the U.S. allows individuals to define themselves based on self-reports, meaning that some with Hispanic ancestry choose not to identify as Hispanic[5]. This fluidity is further influenced by lower immigration levels and high intermarriage rates, which may lead to a growing number of U.S. adults with Hispanic ancestors who do not identify as Hispanic or Latino[8].  

In summary, factors such as generational proximity to immigration, language, familial and cultural ties, and personal identity perceptions shape Hispanic self-identification in the U.S., with significant differences observed across generations.

The experiences of attending Hispanic cultural celebrations and parental pride discussions vary significantly across generations and between self-identified Hispanics and non-Hispanics. Among self-identified Hispanics, immigrant parents are the most likely to take their children to cultural celebrations, with **59%** of immigrant Hispanics reporting that this happened often during their childhood [9]. This percentage decreases in subsequent generations, with **49%** of second-generation and **35%** of third or higher-generation Hispanics recalling similar experiences [6]. ![A chart showing the decline in attendance at cultural celebrations across generations](image3)  

In contrast, self-identified non-Hispanics with Hispanic ancestry report much lower engagement in these cultural activities. Only **9%** of this group say their parents often took them to Latino cultural celebrations, while **60%** say this never happened [1]. ![An illustration highlighting the disconnection from Hispanic cultural activities among self-identified non-Hispanics](image1)  

Parental pride in their country of origin also diminishes across generations. Immigrant and second-generation Hispanics are the most likely to say their parents often talked about their pride in their roots (**57%** and **50%**, respectively). By the third generation, this figure drops to **33%** [7]. ![A visual representation of the decrease in discussions about pride in heritage across generations](image4)  

Overall, these patterns reflect how Hispanic cultural practices and identity fade across generations, particularly among those who do not self-identify as Hispanic, as immigrant connections weaken over time [10].

Across generations, the frequency of attending Latino cultural celebrations and parental pride discussions varies significantly among self-identified Hispanics and non-Hispanics. Immigrant Hispanics are the most engaged, with 59% reporting that their parents often took them to cultural celebrations, while 57% say their parents often talked about pride in their roots [9][10]. This reflects their strong connection to their cultural heritage, as most grew up outside the U.S.

Second-generation Hispanics show a slight decline, with 49% attending cultural celebrations often and 50% having parents who frequently discussed pride in their roots [4][10]. This suggests a continued but somewhat diminished cultural engagement compared to the first generation. 

Third or higher-generation Hispanics experience a more noticeable drop, with only 35% attending cultural celebrations often and 33% recalling frequent discussions about their heritage [4][10]. This aligns with the broader trend of cultural identity fading across generations.

![Decline in cultural celebration attendance across generations](image1)

Among self-identified non-Hispanics with Hispanic ancestry, the distance from cultural roots is even more pronounced. Only 9% report attending Latino cultural celebrations often, and a majority (60%) say this never happened [5]. Similarly, just 9% recall their parents frequently encouraging them to speak Spanish, further highlighting their detachment from Hispanic culture [6].

![Frequency of attending Latino cultural celebrations across generations](image3)

These trends underscore how cultural engagement and identity are closely tied to generational proximity to immigrant experiences. As generations progress, both attendance at cultural celebrations and discussions about heritage decline, particularly among non-Hispanics with Hispanic ancestry.

The experiences and cultural practices of self-identified Hispanics vary significantly across generations, particularly in language dominance, parental encouragement to speak Spanish, and participation in cultural celebrations. 

Among foreign-born self-identified Hispanics, language dominance is primarily in Spanish, with 61% being Spanish dominant and only 7% mostly using English. This shifts dramatically in later generations, with 43% of the second generation and 80% of the third or higher generation being English dominant. Bilingualism is also more common in the second generation (51%) compared to the third or higher generation (24%). ![Language dominance shifts from Spanish to English across generations](image5)

Parental encouragement to speak Spanish is highest among foreign-born Hispanics (85%), but it declines sharply across generations, dropping to 68% for the second generation and just 26% for the third or higher generation. ![Parental encouragement to speak Spanish decreases across generations](image2)

Participation in Hispanic cultural celebrations follows a similar pattern. Among immigrant self-identified Hispanics, 59% report attending such celebrations often during childhood. This share drops to 49% for the second generation and 35% for the third or higher generation. ![Attendance at Hispanic cultural celebrations declines across generations](image1)

In summary, Hispanic cultural practices and language use diminish across generations, with a shift toward English dominance and less engagement in traditional cultural activities as generations become more removed from their immigrant roots.

The connection to Hispanic heritage and language proficiency among self-identified Hispanics shows a notable decline across generations. Among immigrants, 82% feel very or somewhat connected to their country of origin, but this drops to 69% for the second generation and further to 44% for the third or higher generation [7]. ![Connection to heritage declines across generations.](image1)

Language proficiency also shifts significantly. Immigrant Hispanics are predominantly Spanish-dominant (61%), but this drops sharply to 6% in the second generation and becomes negligible in the third generation [2]. Meanwhile, English dominance rises from 7% among immigrants to 43% in the second generation [5]. ![Language proficiency shifts from Spanish to English dominance.](image5)

Despite the decline in Spanish use, there is strong support for its preservation, with 88% of self-identified Hispanics believing it is important for future generations to speak Spanish [9]. Parents’ encouragement of Spanish use also decreases across generations, with only 9% of self-identified non-Hispanics with Hispanic ancestry reporting frequent encouragement to speak Spanish [8]. ![Support for Spanish remains strong despite declining use.](image2)

In summary, as generations progress, self-identified Hispanics experience a weakening connection to their heritage and a shift from Spanish to English proficiency, though there is widespread support for maintaining Spanish in future generations.

Language dominance and the sense of connection to Hispanic heritage vary significantly across different generations of self-identified Hispanics. Among immigrants, Spanish dominance is prevalent, with 61% being more proficient in Spanish than English, and 82% feel very or somewhat connected to their country of origin [1, 3]. By the second generation, this connection declines slightly to 69%, and only 6% are Spanish dominant, with 51% being bilingual [1, 3, 4]. By the third generation, the connection drops further to 44%, and Spanish dominance is nearly non-existent, with only 24% being bilingual [1, 3, 4]. ![Language dominance shifts across generations](image3)

In contrast, English dominance rises sharply across generations. While only 7% of immigrants are English dominant, this figure jumps to 43% in the second generation and continues to increase in the third generation [5]. Despite these trends, there is widespread support for the future use of Spanish, with 88% of self-identified Hispanics and 64% of self-identified non-Hispanics with Hispanic ancestry affirming its importance [9]. ![Decline in Spanish dominance across generations](image4)

The sense of connection to Hispanic heritage also diminishes over generations, with 27% of third or higher-generation Hispanics feeling very or somewhat connected compared to 82% of immigrants [2, 8]. ![Connection to Hispanic heritage varies by generation](image2)

In summary, while Spanish dominance and a strong connection to Hispanic heritage are prevalent among immigrants, both decline significantly across generations, with English dominance increasing and bilingualism becoming less common.

Language dominance and the sense of connection to Hispanic heritage vary significantly across generations of self-identified Hispanics. 

Starting with language dominance, immigrants are predominantly Spanish dominant, with 61% being more proficient in Spanish than English. This shifts in the second generation, where only 6% remain Spanish dominant, and 51% become bilingual. By the third generation, Spanish dominance is nearly absent, with English dominance rising to 43% and bilingualism dropping to 24% [2] ![Language dominance shifts across generations](image2).

Regarding the sense of connection to Hispanic heritage, immigrants feel the strongest ties, with 82% reporting a very or somewhat connected relationship to their country of origin. This decreases to 69% in the second generation and further drops to 44% by the third generation [4] ![Decline in connection to heritage across generations](image5). This generational decline in connection aligns with the reduction in Spanish dominance, as language often serves as a key cultural link. 

In summary, as generations progress, English dominance increases while Spanish proficiency and the sense of connection to Hispanic heritage diminish.

Perceptions of connection to Hispanic heritage and the perceived advantages of being Hispanic vary significantly across different generations of self-identified Hispanics. 

Among immigrants, 82% feel very or somewhat connected to their country of origin, reflecting a strong tie to their ancestral roots[10]. ![82% of immigrant Hispanics feel connected to their country of origin](image3). By the second generation, this connection decreases slightly to 69%, but remains substantial[10]. For third or higher generations, however, only 44% report feeling connected[10]. ![44% of third-generation Hispanics feel connected to their country of origin](image3). This decline suggests that as immigrant roots become more distant, the sense of connection to the home country diminishes.

Regarding perceived advantages, second-generation Hispanics are the most likely to view their Hispanic heritage as beneficial, with 52% saying it has been an advantage in their lives[2]. ![52% of second-generation Hispanics see their heritage as an advantage](image1). In contrast, only 28% of immigrant Hispanics and 24% of third or higher generation Hispanics share this view[2]. ![24% of third-generation Hispanics see their heritage as an advantage](image1). This pattern indicates that second-generation Hispanics may experience the benefits of a bicultural identity, while immigrant and later generations perceive fewer advantages.

Language use also reflects generational differences. While 36% of self-identified Hispanics are bilingual, this decreases to 6% by the third generation, showing a shift toward English dominance[4]. ![6% of third-generation Hispanics are bilingual](image4). Despite this, 88% of self-identified Hispanics believe it is important for future generations to speak Spanish, highlighting a desire to maintain cultural ties[8].

In summary, perceptions of connection to Hispanic heritage and its advantages decline across generations, with second-generation Hispanics feeling the strongest benefits and immigrants maintaining the closest ties to their ancestral roots.

Connections to Hispanic heritage and perceived advantages vary significantly across generations among self-identified Hispanics. Among foreign-born Hispanics, 82% feel very or somewhat connected to their family’s country of origin, while this connection declines to 69% for second-generation Hispanics and further to 44% for the third or higher generation [7]. ![A chart showing the decline in connections to heritage across generations](image4)

Similarly, perceptions of Hispanic heritage as an advantage differ by generation. Half of second-generation Hispanics (52%) view their Hispanic background as an advantage, compared to 28% of immigrant Hispanics and 24% of those in the third or higher generation [8]. ![A chart illustrating perceived advantages of Hispanic heritage across generations](image5)

These trends highlight how generational distance from immigrant roots influences both cultural connections and the perceived benefits of Hispanic identity. As generations progress, connections to ancestral origins weaken, and the perception of Hispanic heritage as an advantage diminishes.

Perceptions of racial identity and the impact of Hispanic heritage vary significantly across generations of self-identified Hispanics in the U.S. Immigrant Hispanics are the most likely to feel connected to their Hispanic heritage, with 78% stating that strangers would perceive them as Hispanic or Latino [10]. However, this perception declines across generations: two-thirds of second-generation Hispanics and only 46% of third or higher generation Hispanics feel the same [10]. ![Decline in perceived Hispanic identity across generations](image5)

The impact of Hispanic heritage also diminishes over generations. While 52% of second-generation Hispanics view their Hispanic background as an advantage, only 28% of immigrant Hispanics and 24% of third or higher generation Hispanics share this view [2]. ![Impact of Hispanic heritage varies by generation](image2) Additionally, immigrant Hispanics are more likely to have predominantly Latino friend networks (77%), a figure that drops to 55% among the second generation and 37% among the third or higher generation [6]. ![Friendship networks shift across generations](image3)

Experiences of discrimination also reflect generational differences. While 39% of self-identified Hispanics report feeling discriminated against due to their Hispanic background, this is less common among higher generations [8]. ![Experiences of discrimination decrease across generations](image4) Immigrant Hispanics feel the most connected to their heritage (27% very/somewhat connected), compared to 56% of third or higher generation Hispanics who feel not very or not at all connected. ![Connection to Hispanic heritage weakens across generations](image1) These findings highlight how generational shifts influence the role and perception of Hispanic identity and heritage in the U.S.

Generational differences among Hispanics significantly influence both their experiences of discrimination and how they are racially identified by others. 

First, the likelihood of experiencing discrimination decreases across generations. Among self-identified Latino immigrants, 42% report experiencing discrimination often (8%) or sometimes (34%) due to their Latino background, while 38% of second-generation Latinos and 29% of third or higher-generation Latinos report the same [6].
